commit_message:
Fix gate scripts to use script dir for sourcing commons

The gate job calls the hook scripts directly, without
changing the current directory.  So we need to source the
commons script from the hook script directory.
Also fix typo in screen dir env var name.

Change-Id: I2fb3759307035e63e6bec9c4f1cdf568e178ebb2

carbonara: raises an error if timestamp before Epoch is sent

Change-Id: Ie974c0bdd28c83a1567a740cf965145572516d1a
(cherry picked from commit 40926fd0ae10c0f985d2c33f58f9c7ab496e5df7)

added_lines: class BeforeEpochError(Exception): """Error raised when a timestamp before Epoch is used.""" def __init__(self, timestamp): self.timestamp = timestamp super(BeforeEpochError, self).__init__( "%s is before Epoch" % timestamp) # NOTE(jd) Our whole serialization system is based on Epoch, and we # store unsigned integer, so we can't store anything before Epoch. # Sorry! if first_timestamp.value < 0: raise BeforeEpochError(first_timestamp)

swift has native retry functionality built in and it's enabled by
default. this means every action we do, even those expected to failed,
will repeat 5 times with an additional backoff mechanism. so every

Change-Id: I4320fb3e8bb30603bd70f8159fbcf855fc4a2880
"}]
commit_message:
disable swift retry

swift has native retry functionality built in and it's enabled by
default. this means every action we do, even those expected to failed,
will repeat 5 times with an additional backoff mechanism. so every
time we have a new metric, there is quite a large delay between first
attempt and confirmation that it does not exist

Change-Id: I4320fb3e8bb30603bd70f8159fbcf855fc4a2880
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/38/290638/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: timeout=conf.swift_timeout, retries=0)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-17 01:17:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5d3283048e68ffed31d309b8d9e873bffc3bece9', 'message': "Aggregate object fixups

aggregate.get(foo, default) calls were changed to getattr(aggregate,
foo, default). This is an incorrect change, because the default of
getattr() is only used if AttributeError is raised. The original get()
call would return the default if the variable was not set, but in order
to get the default with getattr() 'in' has to be used. So now, the
getattr() calls are changed to:

foo = aggregate.foo if 'foo' in aggregate else default

explaining we can do the getattr() and not worry about metadata being
unset, because the compute API always sets it. nova.objects.base also
has a helper method to compare the primitives of two objects to check if
they're equal, so a helper method in the tests were changed over to use
that helper method.

commit_message:
Aggregate object fixups

In the original removal of DictCompat from the Aggregate object, the
aggregate.get(foo, default) calls were changed to getattr(aggregate,
foo, default). This is an incorrect change, because the default of
getattr() is only used if AttributeError is raised. The original get()
call would return the default if the variable was not set, but in order
to get the default with getattr() 'in' has to be used. So now, the
getattr() calls are changed to:

foo = aggregate.foo if 'foo' in aggregate else default

Also, a comment was added for using getattr() on all aggregate fields,
explaining we can do the getattr() and not worry about metadata being
unset, because the compute API always sets it. nova.objects.base also
has a helper method to compare the primitives of two objects to check if
they're equal, so a helper method in the tests were changed over to use
that helper method.

Change-Id: Iee651704c90fcdda0938f907924a4565399601d7
Closes-Bug: #1554617

commit_message:
Correct the wrong usage of 'format' jsonschema keyword in servers API

'format' keyword works for any types. That means for 'port' field,
'null' value never passed the format checks. We should use 'oneOf'
keyword instead of it.

Change-Id: Ic51e9e1c6efadce0a0b4d20a114ca75799fb36a5
Partial-Bug: #1552888

commit_message:
Add ebtables to openstack_hosts role

This change adds the ebtables package and kernel module to the
openstack_host role. This is being added because without it
the neutron linuxbridge agent will not start in a container
sighting that the ebtables filter is missing. While we do not
see this issue in the gate, because its being masked by the os_nova
role, it is a problem on a multi-node setup when using network nodes
that are not also compute nodes. With this simple change neutron had
no issues running in a true multi-node setup.

Change-Id: Ie0cad4efa2d65697a49bbb5da70a59fca85d5fa4
Backport-of: Ib178bbeed14c3e6c17613ad72545bcadf66b98cb
Closes-Bug: 1546818
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/81/291281/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add cron image and playbook

Add cron image and playbook for logrotate.

The "common" Ansible playbook includes configuration files for
logrotate. At this point the operator cannot customize/override the
logrotate configuration.

Closes-Bug: #1553244
Change-Id: Ic9fdda9a273c9ccd90502f0acc7614d2c7157dca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/32/288432/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: FROM {{ namespace }}/{{ image_prefix }}base:{{ tag }} MAINTAINER {{ maintainer }} {% if base_distro in ['centos', 'fedora', 'oraclelinux', 'rhel'] %} RUN yum -y install cronie logrotate \ && yum clean all {% elif base_distro in ['ubuntu'] %} RUN apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends logrotate \ && apt-get clean {% endif %} COPY extend_start.sh /usr/local/bin/kolla_extend_start RUN chmod 755 /usr/local/bin/kolla_extend_start {{ include_footer }}

commit_message:
Revert "Temporarily stop booting ubuntu-trusty in rax-.*"

Do not approve until SSH accessibility issues with ubuntu-trusty in
rax-.* regions have been solved.

This reverts commit 1b50afc32c9b043c3cbf8d38e21e1fedd11c092c.

Change-Id: I80c9877e57a725307793e0ef348fde4bd5b66dbc

commit_message:
Moved CORS middleware configuration into oslo-config-generator

The default values needed for magnum's implementation of cors
middleware have been moved from paste.ini into the configuration
hooks provided by oslo.config. Furthermore, these values have been
added to the default initialization procedure. This ensures
that if a value remains unset in the configuration file, it will
fallback to using sane defaults. It also ensures that an operator
modifying the configuration will be presented with that same
set of defaults.

Change-Id: I7d8f8708d53bbab117600070982ac80482fa0a77
Closes-Bug: 1551836

commit_message:
Ignore TypeErrors on old properties during update

Extend the approach from 1cfde62b2ff8a60c8cc3a9ef4926e5f4a7116aee of
ignoring ValueErrors in the _previous_ properties when doing an update to
also ignoring TypeErrors.

Change-Id: Ic08165fe031e1764cfb34eaf782d3e105f04fee3
Closes-Bug: #1538551
Related-Bug: #1543685
(cherry picked from commit 79c410d92326e63c8bf3752922c35abf6264e211)

This allows to run a command or a script snippet on all overcloud nodes
at the beginning of the upgrade. The intended use is to switch to a new
set of repositories on the overcloud. This is done differently in
different contexts (e.g. upstream vs. downstream), but generally it
should be simple enough to not warrant creation of switchable

commit_message:
Upgrades: initialization command/snippet

This allows to run a command or a script snippet on all overcloud nodes
at the beginning of the upgrade. The intended use is to switch to a new
set of repositories on the overcloud. This is done differently in
different contexts (e.g. upstream vs. downstream), but generally it
should be simple enough to not warrant creation of switchable
"UpgradeInit" resource in the resource registry, and a string
command/snippet parameter should suffice.

Change-Id: I72271170d3f53a5179b3212ec9bae9a6204e29e6

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Example Spec - The title of your blueprint ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/meters-decrepit-period This blueprint add one decrepit period for renamed or deleted meters, in which, end user can still access these meters. Problem description =================== Meter rename and deletion are common, which cause big confusion when end user try to access these meters with original name. This spec introduces one decrepit period, in which obsolete meter appear to be present for one release cycle. The implementation goes in API level to avoid intrusive code changes. Proposed change =============== Introduce one mapping engine in the Ceilometer API level, to map the old meter name to new one when specific meter name is defined in the parameter. E.g. show meter via /v2/meters/{meter_name} For rename meters, one mapping table is provided for old => new mapping. For all deleted meters, they would be mapped to another specific meter with "obsolete." prefix in name. In initialization, one sample with specific volume for each obsolete meter need be created. This is actually parameter translation without intrusive changes. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- This blueprint does not change API itself, but add some compatibility for follwoing API: - Show meter /v2/meters/{meter_name} - Create meter /v2/meters/{meter_name} - Show meter statistics /v2/meters/{meter_name}/statistics In other words, the behavior of these API changes a little bit when meter_name is renamed or deleted. Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- End user would get new meter when access a renamed meter, and a obsolete meter for a deleted meter. This requires end user do more check for returned data. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- Extra mapping function for some meter API, but should be minimal as it just search the mapping table and replace some parameters. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: gzhai<edwin.zhai@intel.com> Other contributors: llu<lianhao.lu@intel.com> Work Items ---------- - Implement a mapping table for all renamed and deleted meters. It can load data from a config file, so end user can easily change the configuration in different release cycle - In the entry of meter API, replace of meter name with hacked one according to the mapping table Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add unit test for renamed and delted meter. Documentation Impact ==================== Update relevant documentation for this. References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/meters-decrepit-period

commit_message:
Support an auto restart on an instance shutdown

Adding a heartbeat pollster to Ceilometer which will use a new method inside
libvirt inspector called 'inspect_heartbeat'.
This method will check the instance state and return a binary value:
1 if the instance state is VIR_DOMAIN_RUNNING and if not it will return 0.

blueprint instance-autorestart

Change-Id: I5057684935ad8260572b6a47724e8bd4b9ab942f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/39/130539/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================================== Instance Auto Restart with a Heartbeat Meter and Ceilometer =========================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/instance-autorestart Problem description =================== In order to support an instance auto restart with Heat, a Ceilometer alarm should be attached to each server. This alarm will monitor the instance health, and will preform a restart according to the alarm condition. The restart process will be executed by using an OS::Heat::HARestart resource in Heat. With the current Ceilometer, which does not support a heartbeat meter the available solutions are: - Using OS::Heat::CWLiteAlarm with cfn-tools - Using OS::Ceilometer::Alarm with cpu_util==0 condition. (workaround) These solutions are not fully working. - OS::Heat::CWLiteAlarm is not working with OS::Ceilometer::Alarm when using an AutoscalingGroup. More details can be found here: https://ask.openstack.org/en/question/47690/create-a-highly-available-auto-scaling-group/ - OS::Ceilometer::Alarm with cpu_util == 0 as a condition works only if an internal shutdown happened. If a compute node has a failure, the cpu_util sample never gets updated. Using insufficient_data_action inside the alarm does not solve this problem since the states of the alarm are changing as followed: alarm/ok -> insufficient_data -> alarm/ok -> insufficient_data etc. That will cause an auto restart even if the instance is up and available. I couldn't find a reason, but when using a binary meter (sample values are 1 or 0) this problem does not happen. Proposed change =============== Add a new pollster to Ceilometer which will monitor the instance health by using the libvirt inspector module. A new method called 'inspect_heartbeat' should be added to libvirt inspector. This method will use the domain state in order to determine the instance health. The meter will return a binary value: 1 if the instance state is VIR_DOMAIN_RUNNING and if not it will return 0. Metric Definition: ================================= ======== ============= ========= Name Type Unit Origin ================================= ======== ============= ========= heartbeat g counter p ================================= ======== ============= ========= Alternatives ------------ The alternative solution is to not attach an alarm to each server that needs to be monitored. It can be done by adding a new property inside OS::Nova::Server (e.g. highly_available) which will tell Heat to keep the instance up and available. It can be something similar to the Monitor resource but it should restart the instances if they are not running. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None. Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- Using a different Ceilometer alarm for each instance may impact Ceilometer performance if multiple instances are being monitored. Adding this feature alone does not affect Ceilometer performance/scalability. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- This feature should have minimal impact on developers for ongoing maintenance. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * erivni Other contributors: * None Ongoing maintainer: * None Work Items ---------- * Add a new Pollster to Ceilometer. * Add a new 'inspect_heartbeat' method to libvirt inspector. * Edit setup.cfg file to support the new Pollster. * Add Unit/Integration test coverage Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit and integration Tests will be added to cover the necessary pollsters calls. Documentation Impact ==================== The Measurement docs need to be updated to reflect the new meter that is been added. References ========== None

Change-Id: I38598a8fce1559b368a1c2219aff94de68c8ea4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/20/163920/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================== Provide inspector implementation for docker hyeprvisor ====================================================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova-docker/+spec/container-metrics Currently, there is no inspector implementation to collect resource utilization metrics for container instances. This feature adds the capability to collect the CPU utilization and memory usage metric for containers. This feature is very much required to configure Alarms and Auto-scaling for containers managed by OpenStack. Problem description =================== As the container instance management from OpenStack is gaining popularity, Container based workloads are trying to exploit the advance OpenStack features like Load Balancer and Auto-Scaling. The Auto-Scaling configuration heavily depends on the telemetry Alarms. Currently, resource utilization alarms cannot be configured for container, as the implementation of inspector for collection containers' matrix is not available. This spec. adds a new inspector for docker containers to collect cpu util and memory usage metrics. The open source service, cAdvisor, with Apache Licence 2i, is leveraged to collect the matrix for containers Proposed change =============== Implements new inspector sub module "docker" for containers which will be installed under "ceilometer/compute/virt". The sub module contains following code "docker/inspector.py" - Implements the DockerInspector with inspect_cpu_util and inspect_memory_usage methods "docker/cadvisorClient.py" - Implements the client communicate with cAdvisor service Alternatives ------------ Instead of using cAdvisor service, the matrix data can be retrieved from the docker container system files. Considering the volume of containers on a single host and high level of scalabilityi, cAdvisor service has been used. Moreover cAdvisor is time proven and wildly used service in community. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- * It has to be explicitly enabled by setting "hypervisor_inspector=docker" in the ceilometer.conf. The configuration update will be taken care by https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-chef/+spec/docker-driver-configuration Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <nkashyap> Other contributors: <None> Ongoing maintainer: <nkashyap> Work Items ---------- * Implement DockerInspector with inspect_cpu_util and inspect_memory_usage methods * Implement cAdvisor Client * Implement related unit tests * Update ceilometer user document Future lifecycle ================ Usual OpenStack support for fixing issues with the inspector. Any cAdvisor related issue will be addressed by cAdvisor community. https://github.com/google/cadvisor Dependencies ============ * Docker runtime * cAdvisor Testing ======= The automated UT will be delivered. No new Tempest testcase is required, this feature overrides the inspect_cpu_util and inspect_memory_usage methods of Inspector (virt/inspector.py) by providing implementation for docker container. Documentation Impact ==================== The refrence of new "docker" inspector will be provided in http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/config-reference/content/section_ceilometer.conf.html References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-chef/+spec/docker-driver-configuration https://github.com/google/cadvisor https://www.docker.com/

commit_message:
Fine Grained Samples and Meters Retention Policy.

Meters and Samples are stored in the database either for a limited amount
of time or until someone manually remove them.

The current time to live configuration does not allow to express different
time intervals for different samples of meters.

This blueprint allows such granular configurations.

Change-Id: If4c1b3db0970f31593a8f60f86387545f33ec665
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/91/128391/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Fine Grained Samples and Meters Retention Policy ================================================ Meters and Samples are stored in the database either for a limited amount of time or until someone manually remove them. The current time to live configuration does not allow to express different time intervals for different samples of meters. Problem description =================== Different Meters and Samples may have different needs in the Billing cycle. Some of these Meters are really important to identify billeable items and hence are required to be stored for a long period of time that may even survive the monthly billing cycle. There are other Meters and Samples that instead are just a validation or notification of intermediate steps and are not that relevant and needed for billing or accounting purposes. This proposal introduces a mechanism to increase the granulariry in selecting which Meters and/or Samples are deleted at given intervals. Proposed change =============== It is possible to leverage the current ceilometer-expirer code to read the configuration or pipeline file and selectively delete Samples and Meters from the database. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Pipeline impact --------------- Potentially the per-meter data can be expressed in the pipeline. TBD. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- There should be a performance benefit from a storage perspective since only the data relevant (and deployment specific) is stored for the longer term. The policy will allow deployer to customize the system to archive useful data for longer and drop less important data in a shorter timeframe optimizing the storage layer. Moreover, now the configuration is deployment and Ceilometer use dependent allowing deployers to skew the usage for Metering or Monitoring depending on needs. Other deployer impact --------------------- Admin can define the time to live for the various Meters. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: fabgia Other contributors: fabgia Ongoing maintainer: fabgia Work Items ---------- TBD. Future lifecycle ================ TBD. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= TBD. Documentation Impact ==================== Adding the specific configuration settings for the Meters/Samples time to live. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Ceilometer cAdvisor driver

User can delpoyed the containers with magnum. ceilometer needs to
collect the meters of these containers deployed by OpenStack. This
blueprint is used to solve this problem.

Change-Id: Id0e5824206e95b1e2ba5572b110698ee418f56d9
blueprint: ceilometer-cadvisor-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/74/247674/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Example Spec - The title of your blueprint ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/ceilometer-cadvisor-driver Problem description =================== User can deploy the contianers with OpenStack magnum[1]. But they can not collect meters of these contianers for ceilometer doesn't support it. And the meters of containers are necessary to the users. In order to help the users to overcome this problem and the mession of the ceilometer is to collect the meters in OpenStack. Ceilometer needs to support to collect the data of the containers deployed by magnum. Proposed change =============== Based on the current design of magnum[1], magnum deploies the containers in the virtual machines with kubernetes api, swarm api and mesos api. cAdvisor is an open source project[2]. It's a running daemon that collects, aggregates, processes and exports information about running containers. For each container, it keeps resource isolation parameters and historical resource usage, including CPU, memory, disk and network statistics. And it also support REST API. In order to solve the problem, need to complete the following tasks. a. Implement a notification agent. It will be installed in the host where the VMs are running and the containers are deployed in these VMs. The agent can pull data of the containers from each cAdvisor installed in the VMs. It will keep the corresponding data, including host id, the instance id of VM and name of the container. b. Implement the cache mechanism in the agent side. If 10 VMs are running in a host and 10 containers are running in each VM, 10*10 data will be generated and send to ceilometer in each polling. It will have some performance problems when many containers have been deploied. So the agent need to notify the ceilometer only when the meters have changed. c. In ceilometer server side, need to implement the transformation function. In order to reduce the impact to network, the data sent to ceilometer needs to be simple. Based on the current ceilometer mechanism, it is easy to implement. Alternatives ------------ Implement a plugin to invoke the Docker api directly. The advantage of this blueprint: a. cAdvisor is a popular monitor tool to collect the contianer data. We don't need to re-invent the wheel. It has REST api and we don't cover the currency work in the future when Docker apis have change. b. Now magnum deploies the containers in the VM. If we implement a new plugin to collect the container data. We need to let user to install it in every VM. I think it's not friendly to user. Now the cAdvisor has been deployed by default when usring the kubernetes. If the users use magnum with mesos or swarm, they can just write a init-config script to run the cAdvisor container when booting VM. Data model impact ----------------- Need to add the meters of container, including container CPU, Memory, Disk. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- * Is yet another agent required to host the data acquisition pollsters or notification handlers? Yes * If accommodated in an existing agent, is the scaling of that agent impacted? No * Is explicit configuration of the source and/or transformations required in the pipeline.yaml? Yes * Is the typical cadence of data acquisition likely in practice to be unusually frequent or infrequent? Yes * Is an explicit resource discovery extension required to retrieve target resources? No * Is AMQP the appropriate publication conduit for these data? Yes * Is any change required to the metering message signature verification used by the collector? No Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- The cache mechanism is used in the agent side. And the agent just notifies the ceilometer server when data have been changed. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- jizilian Primary assignee: jizilian Other contributors: Ongoing maintainer: Work Items ---------- a. Implement the agent to pull the cAdvisor periodically b. Implement the cache mechanism of agent c. Send the notification to ceilometer d. Deal with the notification in the ceilometer server side Future lifecycle ================ Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= UT cases and test during the development will cover the test. Documentation Impact ==================== Need to update the doc about collecting the meters about container. References ========== [1]https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Magnum [2]https://github.com/google/cadvisor

commit_message:
Combine derived and heterogeneous meters

Currently, the multi meter arithmetic transformer can be used to combine
only samples of simple and homogeneous meters.

The purpose of this spec is to enable the capability to combine
derived and heterogeneous meters, like cpu_util and memory.usage.

Change-Id: Ic7af2a249a57e014b3cedba1c42dd1da19d78ffe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/88/179588/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Combine samples of derived and heterogeneous meters =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/combine-derived-heterogeneous-meters The goal of this blueprint is to enable the capability to combine samples of derived and heterogeneous meters. For example:: cpu_memory_usage = 0.5*cpu_util/100 + 0.5*memory.usage/100 This has been already realized in [1]_. Problem description =================== Currently, the multi meter arithmetic transformer can be used to combine only samples of simple and homogeneous meters. Simple meters are meters whose samples are produced directly by sources, without transformations. An example is the *cpu* meter, produced by the *cpu* source. Homogeneous meters are meters whose samples are produced by the same source. Examples are *disk.read.requests* and *disk.write.requests*, produced by the *disk* source. With this blueprint we want to enable the capability to combine derived and heterogeneous meters. A derived meter is a meter whose samples have been subjects to one or more transformations. An example is the *cpu_util* meter, that in libvirt is produced from samples of the *cpu* meter after having applied the *rate of change* transformer. Heterogeneous meters are meters whose samples are produced by different sources. Examples are *cpu_util* and *memory_usage*. By enabling this capability we increase the flexibility of the multi meter arithmetic transformer. This work can be useful for end users (e.g. autoscaling) and cloud operators (e.g. infastructure monitoring). Proposed change =============== We must modify the pipeline definition. A pipeline is currenty defined as a *coupling between a source and a sink*. We want to redefine it as the association between * **one or more sources** and a sink*. In this way we can apply the multi meter arithmetic transformer on heterogeneous meters. In order to combine samples that have been subject to different type of transformations, we must add a new mechanism called the *Selective Transformer*, a transformer that applies transformation to a subset of samples in a pipeline. An example of configuration of a *Selective Transformer* is the following:: - name: cpu_util_memory_usage_sink transformers: - name: "rate_of_change" parameters: apply_to: - "cpu" target: name: "cpu_util" unit: "%" type: "gauge" scale: "100.0/(10**9*(resource_metadata.cpu_number or 1))" - name: "arithmetic" parameters: apply_to: - "*" target: name: "cpu.util.memory.usage" unit: "" type: "cumulative" expr: "0.5*$(cpu_util)/100 + 0.5*$(memory.usage)/100" publishers: - rpc:// The **apply_to** parameter of the *rate_of_change* transformer is needed in order to apply this transformation only to samples of the *cpu* meter, thus producing samples of the *cpu_util* meter. Than the multi meter arithmetic trasformer is applied to the samples of *cpu_util* and *memory.usage*, and samples of *cpu.util.memory.usage* meter are produced. To enable the Selective Transformer, a simple modification to sample management is needed. Before applying the transformation on a sample (function *handle_sample* of each transformer) we must check that the attribute *apply_to* in that transformer contains the name of the meter of the sample. If not, return the sample unmodified, else apply the transformation. Alternatives ------------ Currently we can combine heterogeneous samples only by querying ceilometer api and manually combine samples, although this solution is not compatibile with the alarm mechanism. Combining samples that have been subject to different transformations, can be done by introducing another type of publisher, which publish into another sink. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Pipeline impact --------------- We must modify the pipeline definition. Currenty is has a source and a sink. We want it to be an association between (possibly) multiple sources and a sink. We must add a new parameter into the *pipeline.yaml* file to define a *selective transformer* and check this parameter before applying a transformation to a sample (function *handle_sample*). Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: claudio-pupparo Ongoing maintainer: claudio-pupparo Work Items ---------- None. Future lifecycle ================ Modifying the pipeline definition is a critical task that impacts on other's blueprints, so this new feature must be heavily monitored in the next cycles. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= We should rewrite many unit cases that depends on the previoulsy definition of pipeline. Documentation Impact ==================== We should describe the new capabilities of the multi meter arithmetic transformer and the selective transformer. References ========== .. [1] https://github.com/MisterPup/Ceilometer-Juno-Extension

commit_message:
Fix sriov_iommu_check for role-based deployment

Role-based deployment does not support "shell" tasks, only "puppet".
So we need to wrap shell task into puppet Exec. We can remove it
later when role-based deployment is deprecated.

Closes-bug: #1555681
Change-Id: Ia81efb58e18385a9f7f2884412b231ddf7bca09a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/62/291262/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: notice('MODULAR: sriov_iommu_check.pp') # TODO: (adidenko) Remove this puppet wrapper aroung exec and move task into # plain "shell" type when role-based deployment is deprecated or at least # "shell" tasks are allowed in "deploy" stage $script = '/etc/puppet/modules/osnailyfacter/modular/netconfig/sriov_iommu_check.rb' exec {"sriov_iommu_check": command => "ruby $script", path => ['/usr/bin', '/usr/sbin', '/sbin', '/bin'] }

commit_message:
Revert "Time to get rid of most vestiges of slave_of"

This reverts commit 0c94a5bae0aacff7fde9a9742b7d526096e51767

Removing 'slave_of' from the instance create API was a
backward incompatible change.

The parameter should be removed if/when trove has a new
version in their API, or adopts microversions.

This change depends on the change which reverts the
removal of slave_of from python-troveclient since
the tests depend on that argument being available in the
client.

Note that the tests could later be updated to no longer
use 'slave_of' to avoid a deprecation warning from the
client.

Conflicts:
        trove/tests/api/replication.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict was due to
5515c5291cc0ebacad59973c87ba696b5ffc5efa.

Depends-On: I9b3ec6c101a89f30e61fc683808506c404e5474f

Change-Id: Ib6811293d99fbc20f6a52ee10de7c98bfb682b18
Partial-Bug: #1538506

commit_message:
Fixing mapping schema to allow local user

Mapping to local user was broken since we introduced JSON schema for
mapping. That was because we've never accounted for the "type" attribute
in the "user" object. This patch add it back so that we can map a
remote user to either a local or ephemeral user.

Closes-Bug: 1555403

Change-Id: I7ae69b143e1bdade3e8ea9e2036227c7a38b3b10
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/04/291004/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Exclude python-troveclient 2.1.0

Change a5234f0a07230e0d8195687e033adfe4cc0ad522 in python-troveclient
2.1.0 is a backward incompatible change.

Change I9b3ec6c101a89f30e61fc683808506c404e5474f reverts the
problem in the client and adds a compat shim until liberty-eol and
should be released in 2.2.0 for troveclient.

Change-Id: Ifa9b07f7c4e93735aec33adb454e920c3c2d7141
Partial-Bug: #1538506

commit_message:
Fix keystone-manage example command path

Whether the user is using tox or has installed keystone globally, the
keystone-manage command should already be in their path. The keystone
repo doesn't have a bin/ directory so trying to call
bin/keystone-manage from the root of the repo will result in an error.
Moreover, other references to keystone-manage in this page do not
specify a path. This patch fixes the instruction and makes it
consistent with the rest of the document.

Change-Id: I93f1aca9bdef0fa3ef4937ef616157d1e1b6fbe9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/04/290904/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $ keystone-manage db_sync

This change adds in the nova_api db migration that has to happen
within mitaka. This is a new required DB though the DB entry has
existed since Kilo.

  * The SHA was moved forward to the new version of nova to support
    this change. This was done independently of the rest of the stack
    to ensure functionality of this new DB.

    additional task to execute the nova api_db sync.
  * Additionally, new DB tunings were added to the defaults file and
    an entry to the secrets file to support a new  db user and
    password.

commit_message:
Add support for the nova_api db

This change adds in the nova_api db migration that has to happen
within mitaka. This is a new required DB though the DB entry has
existed since Kilo.

Change:
  * The SHA was moved forward to the new version of nova to support
    this change. This was done independently of the rest of the stack
    to ensure functionality of this new DB.
  * An entry was added to the secrets file to support a new db user
    and password.
  * The requirements repo was rev'd forward to support the new
    requirements within nova.

Depends-On: If63b541bfaf91333ac5963d391e6058ac8254eec
UpgradeImpact
Change-Id: I711018f4f1f27d667a3dda94a01dc76616f98f4c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/32/274932/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## DB API nova_api_galera_user: nova_api nova_api_galera_database: nova_api nova_api_db_max_overflow: 10 nova_api_db_max_pool_size: 120 nova_api_db_pool_timeout: 30

commit_message:
Make all tox targets constrained

Since lbaas gate has not switched to -constraints targets yet, we can
remove them right away.

Note: override install_command for releasenotes and cover targets since
corresponding gate jobs do not provide constraints file yet.

Change-Id: If3c143153d0a09378092791e76f1a728fb978aed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/31/288431/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {toxinidir}/tools/tox_install.sh {env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt} {opts} {packages}
deleted_lines: constraints: {[testenv:common-constraints]install_command} {toxinidir}/tools/tox_install.sh unconstrained {opts} {packages}[testenv:common-constraints] install_command = {toxinidir}/tools/tox_install.sh constrained -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt} {opts} {packages} [testenv:pep8-constraints] install_command = {[testenv:common-constraints]install_command} commands = flake8 # pylint --rcfile=.pylintrc --output-format=colorized {posargs:neutron_lbaas} neutron-db-manage --subproject neutron-lbaas --config-file neutron_lbaas/tests/etc/neutron.conf check_migration whitelist_externals = {[testenv:pep8]whitelist_externals} [testenv:cover-constraints] install_command = {[testenv:common-constraints]install_command} commands = python setup.py testr --coverage --coverage-package-name=neutron_lbaas --testr-args='{posargs}' [testenv:venv-constraints] install_command = {[testenv:common-constraints]install_command} commands = {posargs} [testenv:docs-constraints] install_command = {[testenv:common-constraints]install_command} commands = {[testenv:docs]commands} [testenv:py34-constraints] install_command = {[testenv:common-constraints]install_command} commands = {[testenv:py34]commands}

commit_message:
Cleanup unused Oslo Incubator _i18n

As this project has already graduated i18n, this seeks to remove the
unused Incubutor code.

Implements: blueprint graduate-oslo-i18n [1]
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/graduate-oslo-i18n

Change-Id: Iaaeeb13acc395aa7556858a55262c0da03c28a17
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/08/291308/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """oslo.i18n integration module. See http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/usage.html """ try: import oslo_i18n # NOTE(dhellmann): This reference to o-s-l-o will be replaced by the # application name when this module is synced into the separate # repository. It is OK to have more than one translation function # using the same domain, since there will still only be one message # catalog. _translators = oslo_i18n.TranslatorFactory(domain='designate') # The primary translation function using the well-known name "_" _ = _translators.primary # Translators for log levels. # # The abbreviated names are meant to reflect the usual use of a short # name like '_'. The "L" is for "log" and the other letter comes from # the level. _LI = _translators.log_info _LW = _translators.log_warning _LE = _translators.log_error _LC = _translators.log_critical except ImportError: # NOTE(dims): Support for cases where a project wants to use # code from oslo-incubator, but is not ready to be internationalized # (like tempest) _ = _LI = _LW = _LE = _LC = lambda x: x

commit_message:
Improve error code for invalid secret creation with KMIP

When using KMIP backend, error handling around invalid key
specificaion is modified to return more specific 400 error.

Change-Id: I080aac88c2a055ecfc59e63f840c0d2d12c38d00
Closes-Bug: 1546366

added_lines: raise SecretStorePluginNotFound()

subject: Give manila-image-elements its own acls
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-09 21:28:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/24eeb04168bcb1969d91640c6735bd2d8de8b5df', 'message': 'Give manila-image-elements its own acls

It looks like manila-image-elements was setup to inherit
ACLs from manila, but unlike the manila project,
manila-image-elements is not release managed and does not
have stable branches. Tagging should be done by the
manila-release group rather than the formal release process.

Change-Id: I5402978a9c95d58f8e1a62b732ce92234a2bcd5b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-10 15:59:42.000000000', 'files': ['gerrit/acls/openstack/manila-image-elements.config', 'gerrit/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/3d252804312ae5e7605c6104881bd8782d8b9440', 'message': 'Give manila-image-elements its own acls

It looks like manila-image-elements was setup to inherit
ACLs from manila, but unlike the manila project,
manila-image-elements is not release managed and does not
have stable branches. Tagging should be done by the
manila-release group rather than the formal release process.

Change-Id: I5402978a9c95d58f8e1a62b732ce92234a2bcd5b

commit_message:
Give manila-image-elements its own acls

It looks like manila-image-elements was setup to inherit
ACLs from manila, but unlike the manila project,
manila-image-elements is not release managed and does not
have stable branches. Tagging should be done by the
manila-release group rather than the formal release process.

Change-Id: I5402978a9c95d58f8e1a62b732ce92234a2bcd5b

commit_message:
Install cron job to flush keystone tokens.

This change adds a cron job definition to flush the keystone tokens
once every hour. Without this, the keystone database grows unbounded,
which can be problematic in production environments.

This change introduces a new keystone-token-flush templated cron job,
which will run the keystone-manage token_flush command as the keystone
user once per hour. This change honors the use-syslog setting by
sending output of the command either to the keystone-token-flush.log
file or to the syslog using the logger exec.

Only the juju service leader will have the cron job active in order to
prevent multiple units from running the token_flush at the concurrently.

Change-Id: I21be3b23a8fe66b67fba0654ce498d62b3afc2ac
Closes-Bug: #1467832

commit_message:
Rename methods's name to add consistan

In the "validators.py" file, the predominant and correct naming standard
for methods to validate a field has the syntax: validate_<field's name>.

Some methods have been renamed to follow a standard and add consistancy
in the file.

Change-Id: I1ae647136a2eb438de9c72af138bf7188b1bdf05
Closes-bug: #1554239

commit_message:
Upgrade of Cinder block storage nodes

This introduces upgrades for Cinder block storage nodes. Currently
Cinder doesn't support upgrade level pinning and cannot safely deal with
version skew. This means that we have to upgrade Cinder storage nodes in
sync with controller nodes (after they were taken down for upgrade,
before they are brought back up) to ensure that Cinder services perform
AMQP communication only within the same major version of Cinder.

According to our current knowledge, Cinder block storage nodes are the
only node type that will have to be upgraded in sync with controllers.

Change-Id: Icec913c015eff744b0f31b513176b4b657df43af
(cherry picked from commit 7455f1afc3d2272a60d93672018324926c9eaa0d)

commit_message:
Use fstrim to prep the block device

This cuts the image size down alot, esspecially if there were lots of
small file deletes.

The fstrim utility is in the util-linux package and should be on
most all systems. fstrim also works with XFS, ext4, btrfs, etc
prodiving the kernel is new enough.

A reduction of 25% or more in size is common.

Change-Id: I49cd91e02f2d83d6b7799aff8c8cee03fde5a0e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/51/291351/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: To produce the smallest image the utility fstrim is used. When deleting a file the space is simply marked as free on the disk, the file is still there until it is overwritten. fstrim informs the underlying disk to drop those bytes the end result of which is like writting zeros over those sectors. The same effect could be achieved by creating a large file full of zeros and removing that file, however that method is far more IO intensive.

commit_message:
Use service tenant for ceilometer

Configure ceilometer to use the service tenant instead of the admin
tenant.  Using the admin tenant is not required and a security risk.

This brings the ceilometer configuration in line with the
recommendations from the official installation guide:
http://docs.openstack.org/kilo/install-guide/install/yum/content/ceilometer-controller-install.html

Change-Id: I40dd4543580332a46cde96f4bca639eb777ac7a8
Partial-Bug: #1358237
(cherry picked from commit 99b132b0ff258b1b7fc8eca0cbeec69613b59175)

commit_message:
Remove trailing / on keystone admin endpoint

With the trailing /, puppet is generating an admin endpoint that
looks like http://9.1.1.1:35357//v2.0, which causes problems when
the client actually tries to talk to it.

Change-Id: Id7fd26bf6783cc6041f477670f98717b2658b964

commit_message:
devstack:  release definition for lithium 0.3.4-SR4 and 0.3.5 snapshot

As Lithium 0.3.4-SR4 is released, this patch adds the definitions of
lithium 0.3.4-SR4 and 0.3.5-snapshot, removes 0.3.[0123]-snapshot
because the repo of 0.3.[0123]-snapshot in nexus were deleted.

Conflicts:
	devstack/pre_test_hook.sh
	devstack/settings.odl

Change-Id: I870c9cd4cb0022cd74225e87ef4f9be8b615e685
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <isaku.yamahata@intel.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4b932f61aa9b5cfdfecc1eb6ef89ea6c310ee2c5)

subject: Add a ceph-storage node upgrade script for the upgrade workflow
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-08 12:36:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/431aff992b51dfdd5be1e3c28bd977d8031a7d8c', 'message': 'Add a ceph-storage node upgrade script for the upgrade workflow

This adds delivery of an upgrade script to any ceph-storage nodes
during the script delivery that comes first during the upgrade
workflow.

The controllers have the ceph-mon whilst the ceph-osds are on the
ceph-storage nodes. The ceph-mons will be updated first as part of
the heat-driven controller upgrade, and ceph-osds on ceph nodes are
upgraded with the upgrade-non-controller.sh tripleo-common script
as with compute and swift nodes.

Also slight rename for the ObjectStorageConfig/Deployment here for

commit_message:
Add a ceph-storage node upgrade script for the upgrade workflow

This adds delivery of an upgrade script to any ceph-storage nodes
during the script delivery that comes first during the upgrade
workflow.

The controllers have the ceph-mon whilst the ceph-osds are on the
ceph-storage nodes. The ceph-mons will be updated first as part of
the heat-driven controller upgrade, and ceph-osds on ceph nodes are
upgraded with the upgrade-non-controller.sh tripleo-common script
as with compute and swift nodes.

Also slight rename for the ObjectStorageConfig/Deployment here for
consistency.

Change-Id: I12abad5548dcb019ade9273da06fe66fd97f54cc

commit_message:
Add generic timeseries support

This implementation add the support for InfluxDB.
Other drivers can be implemented later (OpenTSDB, KairosDB).

Change-Id: I4e0213322cce606cedaff21fbe38b276393bb245
Implements: blueprint generic-timeseries

commit_message:
Deprecated tox -downloadcache option removed

Caching is enabled by default from pip version 6.0

More info:
https://testrun.org/tox/latest/config.html#confval-downloadcache=path
https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/#caching

Change-Id: I20e507bbd84c269181ac8172c31f038537fde625

commit_message:
Fix 500 server error invalid transport key during secret creation

If a user creates a secret and passes in a transport key reference
that does not exist, the server responds to a 500 error. It has
been fixed to return a 400 error with a message that says transport key
not found.

Change-Id: I3c6dd459efc4aec611f88a73b118cd3f36444b63
Closes-Bug: #1554172

added_lines: def _transport_key_in_request_not_found(): """Throw exception for providing a non existing transport key. Throw an exception if a transport key reference is passed in a request but the transport key does not exist """ pecan.abort(400, u._('Transport key was not found')) try: new_secret, transport_key_model = plugin.store_secret( unencrypted_raw=data.get('payload'), content_type_raw=data.get('payload_content_type', 'application/octet-stream'), content_encoding=data.get('payload_content_encoding'), secret_model=secret_model, project_model=project, transport_key_needed=transport_key_needed, transport_key_id=data.get('transport_key_id')) except exception.TransportKeyNotFound: LOG.info(u._LE('Transport key %s was not found'), ) _transport_key_in_request_not_found()
deleted_lines: new_secret, transport_key_model = plugin.store_secret( unencrypted_raw=data.get('payload'), content_type_raw=data.get('payload_content_type', 'application/octet-stream'), content_encoding=data.get('payload_content_encoding'), secret_model=secret_model, project_model=project, transport_key_needed=transport_key_needed, transport_key_id=data.get('transport_key_id'))

commit_message:
Remove unused pngmath Sphinx extension

There's no RST file that uses ".. math" and thus
the pngmath Sphinx extension is not used and can
get removed.

Change-Id: I3ea4b529025c8ac3c4092f3720124647861e6668

commit_message:
Remove default event handler from theme switch links

On Chrome the default <a> event handler was firing after reload()
resulting in a change of location.

This was particularly noticeable on the new angular Swift UI.

Change-Id: I5b644f3b899a5a8c598ceae7cdb76a1e9fd89ebf
Closes-Bug: 1555429
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/67/290967/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // prevent the default <a> click handler from firing - on // Chrome it confuses the reload() we do below e.preventDefault();

commit_message:
Split out domain config driver and manager tests

The existing DomainConfigTest class was a mixture of manager and
driver tests. These are now split into two separate test classes.

One test is moved to the manager level, since it was
unnecessarily written at the driver level.

Change-Id: Ib473a5a9ae91332b98aebbf1884a5f7235cd5308

commit_message:
Deprecated tox -downloadcache option removed

Caching is enabled by default from pip version 6.0

More info:
https://testrun.org/tox/latest/config.html#confval-downloadcache=path
https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/#caching

Change-Id: If7b9039c7ab8435e64f77e8b4a859c66df3af2fb

commit_message:
Replace deprecated LOG.warn with LOG.warning

LOG.warn is deprecated. It still used in a few places.
Updated to non-deprecated LOG.warning.

Change-Id: I1654e77287c610681f297646625e8bfda27e774d
Closes-Bug:#1508442

commit_message:
Update Python classifier for 3.4

Barbican is tested with py34, but the classifier states only 2.7
is supported. This adds 3.4 to the list.

Change-Id: Ic7b14714d9a17a3370a8eb138bf4940ffa4ba999

commit_message:
Change render_unsets default to False

The API WSME Types all inherit a to_dict method that accepts as a parameter
render_unsets. It is currently set to True by default but should be False for
consistency and also because it just makes better sense. This has caused some
unnecessary workarounds and work before it was known this existed.

Closes-Bug: 1555493
Change-Id: Idd21a003c0b1e3092f979013f8c19d75f17d0249

commit_message:
Manage and unmanage snapshot

Add APIs to support manage and unmanage share snapshots.
Also add support in the Generic driver.
This only supports for DHSS=False driver mode.

Add provider_location column to the share_snapshots table
to save data used to identify the snapshot on the backend.

Also need to bump microversion.

APIImpact
DocImpact
Change-Id: I87a066173c85d969607d132accd9f0e9bd49c235
Implements: blueprint manage-unmanage-snapshot
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/42/249542/58 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from manila.api.v1 import snapshot_manage from manila.api.v1 import snapshot_unmanage self.resources["snapshot_manage"] = snapshot_manage.create_resource() mapper.resource("snapshot_manage", # TODO(xyang): Move to shares controller and # remove this. "os-share-manage-snapshot", controller=self.resources["snapshot_manage"]) self.resources["snapshot_unmanage"] = ( snapshot_unmanage.create_resource()) mapper.resource("snapshot_unmanage", # TODO(xyang): Move to shares controller and # remove this. "os-share-unmanage-snapshot", controller=self.resources["snapshot_unmanage"], member={'unmanage': 'POST'})

commit_message:
Remove bare-trusty from projects.yaml

Remove all bare-trusty occurences from projects.yaml. These are not
needed any more, all jobs are run on specific nodes.

subject: Network guide: LBaaS v2 configuration guide
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-09 14:59:05.000000000', 'files': ['doc/networking-guide/source/figures/lbaasv2-diagram.png', 'doc/networking-guide/source/figures/lbaasv2-diagram.svg', 'doc/networking-guide/source/adv-config-lbaas.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/3acad8a79e626d218da4feccb5ea552dbc6b67e2', 'message': 'Network guide: LBaaS v2 configuration guide

This patch adds LBaaS v2 configuration steps and explains more of the
differences between v1 and v2 load balancers.

Change-Id: I0e828da3cb652083f7af0f2aeb500ac3e0089869
(cherry picked from commit 1bb5545ca4797d5b0aa16319de48a8eaf32e2792)
'}]
commit_message:
Network guide: LBaaS v2 configuration guide

This patch adds LBaaS v2 configuration steps and explains more of the
differences between v1 and v2 load balancers.

Closes-bug: 1544333

Change-Id: I0e828da3cb652083f7af0f2aeb500ac3e0089869
(cherry picked from commit 1bb5545ca4797d5b0aa16319de48a8eaf32e2792)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/57/290557/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================== Load Balancer as a Service (LBaaS) ================================== The Networking service offers two load balancer implementations through the ``neutron-lbaas`` service plug-in: * LBaaS v1: introduced in Juno (deprecated in Liberty) * LBaaS v2: introduced in Kilo Both implementations use agents. The agents handle the HAProxy configuration and manage the HAProxy daemon. LBaaS v2 adds the concept of listeners to the LBaaS v1 load balancers. LBaaS v2 allows you to configure multiple listener ports on a single load balancer IP address. Another LBaaS v2 implementation, `Octavia`_, has a separate API and separate worker processes that build load balancers within virtual machines on hypervisors that are managed by the Compute service. You do not need an agent for Octavia. Currently, no migration path exists between v1 and v2 load balancers. If you choose to switch from v1 to v2, you must recreate all load balancers, pools, and health monitors. .. _octavia: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/octavia/ LBaaS v1 ~~~~~~~~ LBaaS v1 is deprecated in the Liberty release. These links provide more details about how LBaaS v1 works and how to configure it: * `Load-Balancer-as-a-Service (LBaaS) overview`_ * `Basic Load-Balancer-as-a-Service operations`_ .. _Load-Balancer-as-a-Service (LBaaS) overview: http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/networking_introduction.html#load-balancer-as-a-service-lbaas-overview .. _Basic Load-Balancer-as-a-Service operations: http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/networking_adv-features.html#basic-load-balancer-as-a-service-operations LBaaS v2 ~~~~~~~~ LBaaS v2 has several new concepts to understand: .. image:: figures/lbaasv2-diagram.png :alt: LBaaS v2 layout Load balancer The load balancer occupies a neutron network port and has an IP address assigned from a subnet. Listener Load balancers can listen for requests on multiple ports. Each one of those ports is specified by a listener. Pool A pool holds a list of members that serve content through the load balancer. Member Members are servers that serve traffic behind a load balancer. Each member is specified by the IP address and port that it uses to serve traffic. Health monitor Members may go offline from time to time and health monitors divert traffic away from members that are not responding properly. Health monitors are associated with pools. LBaaS v2 has multiple implementations via different service plug-ins. The two most common implementations use either an agent or the Octavia services. Both implementations use the `LBaaS v2 API`_. .. _LBaaS v2 API: http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2-ext.html#lbaas-v2.0 Configuring LBaaS v2 with an agent ---------------------------------- #. Add the LBaaS v2 service plug-in to the ``service_plugins`` configuration directive in ``/etc/neutron/neutron.conf``. The plug-in list is comma-separated: .. code-block:: console service_plugins = [existing service plugins],neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer.plugin.LoadBalancerPluginv2 #. Add the LBaaS v2 service provider to the ``service_provider`` configuration directive within the ``[service_providers]`` section in ``/etc/neutron/neutron.conf``: .. code-block:: console service_provider = LOADBALANCERV2:Haproxy:neutron_lbaas.drivers.haproxy.plugin_driver.HaproxyOnHostPluginDriver:default If you have existing service providers for other networking service plug-ins, such as VPNaaS or FWaaS, add the ``service_provider`` line shown above in the ``[service_providers]`` section as a separate line. These configuration directives are repeatable and are not comma-separated. #. Run the ``neutron-lbaas`` database migration: .. code-block:: console neutron-db-manage --service lbaas upgrade head #. If you have deployed LBaaS v1, **stop the LBaaS v1 agent now**. The v1 and v2 agents **cannot** run simultaneously. #. Start the LBaaS v2 agent: .. code-block:: console neutron-lbaasv2-agent \ --config-file /etc/neutron/neutron.conf \ --config-file /etc/neutron/lbaas_agent.ini #. Restart the Network service to activate the new configuration. You are now ready to create load balancers with the LBaaS v2 agent. Configuring LBaaS v2 with Octavia --------------------------------- Octavia provides additional capabilities for load balancers, including using a compute driver to build instances that operate as load balancers. The `Hands on Lab - Install and Configure OpenStack Octavia`_ session at the OpenStack Summit in Tokyo provides an overview of Octavia. The DevStack documentation offers a `simple method to deploy Octavia`_ and test the service with redundant load balancer instances. If you already have Octavia installed and configured within your environment, you can configure the Network service to use Octavia: #. Add the LBaaS v2 service plug-in to the ``service_plugins`` configuration directive in ``/etc/neutron/neutron.conf``. The plug-in list is comma-separated: .. code-block:: console service_plugins = [existing service plugins],neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer.plugin.LoadBalancerPluginv2 #. Add the Octavia service provider to the ``service_provider`` configuration directive within the ``[service_providers]`` section in ``/etc/neutron/neutron.conf``: .. code-block:: console service_provider = LOADBALANCERV2:Octavia:neutron_lbaas.drivers.octavia.driver.OctaviaDriver:default Ensure that the LBaaS v1 and v2 service providers are removed from the ``[service_providers]`` section. They are not used with Octavia. **Verify that all LBaaS agents are stopped.** #. Restart the Network service to activate the new configuration. You are now ready to create and manage load balancers with Octavia. .. _Hands on Lab - Install and Configure OpenStack Octavia: https://www.openstack.org/summit/tokyo-2015/videos/presentation/rsvp-required-hands-on-lab-install-and-configure-openstack-octavia .. _simple method to deploy Octavia: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/devstack/guides/devstack-with-lbaas-v2.html LBaaS v2 operations ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The same neutron commands are used for LBaaS v2 with an agent or with Octavia. Building an LBaaS v2 load balancer ---------------------------------- #. Start by creating a load balancer on a network. In this example, the ``private`` network is an isolated network with two web server instances: .. code-block:: console $ neutron lbaas-loadbalancer-create --name test-lb private-subnet #. You can view the load balancer status and IP address with the ``lbaas-loadbalancer-show`` command: .. code-block:: console $ neutron lbaas-loadbalancer-show test-lb +---------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | description | | | id | 7780f9dd-e5dd-43a9-af81-0d2d1bd9c386 | | listeners | {"id": "23442d6a-4d82-40ee-8d08-243750dbc191"} | | | {"id": "7e0d084d-6d67-47e6-9f77-0115e6cf9ba8"} | | name | test-lb | | operating_status | ONLINE | | provider | haproxy | | provisioning_status | ACTIVE | | tenant_id | fbfce4cb346c4f9097a977c54904cafd | | vip_address | 192.168.1.22 | | vip_port_id | 9f8f8a75-a731-4a34-b622-864907e1d556 | | vip_subnet_id | f1e7827d-1bfe-40b6-b8f0-2d9fd946f59b | +---------------------+------------------------------------------------+ This load balancer is active and ready to serve traffic on ``192.168.1.22``. #. Verify that the load balancer is responding to pings before moving further: .. code-block:: console $ ping -c 4 192.168.1.22 PING 192.168.1.22 (192.168.1.22) 56(84) bytes of data. 64 bytes from 192.168.1.22: icmp_seq=1 ttl=62 time=0.410 ms 64 bytes from 192.168.1.22: icmp_seq=2 ttl=62 time=0.407 ms 64 bytes from 192.168.1.22: icmp_seq=3 ttl=62 time=0.396 ms 64 bytes from 192.168.1.22: icmp_seq=4 ttl=62 time=0.397 ms --- 192.168.1.22 ping statistics --- 4 packets transmitted, 4 received, 0% packet loss, time 2997ms rtt min/avg/max/mdev = 0.396/0.402/0.410/0.020 ms Adding an HTTP listener ----------------------- #. With the load balancer online, you can add a listener for plaintext HTTP traffic on port 80: .. code-block:: console $ neutron lbaas-listener-create \ --name test-lb-http \ --loadbalancer test-lb \ --protocol HTTP \ --protocol-port 80 #. You can begin building a pool and adding members to the pool to serve HTTP content on port 80. For this example, the web servers are ``192.168.1.16`` and ``192.168.1.17``: .. code-block:: console $ neutron lbaas-pool-create \ --name test-lb-pool-http \ --lb-algorithm ROUND_ROBIN \ --listener test-lb-http \ --protocol HTTP $ neutron lbaas-member-create \ --subnet private-subnet \ --address 192.168.1.16 \ --protocol-port 80 \ test-lb-pool-http $ neutron lbaas-member-create \ --subnet private-subnet \ --address 192.168.1.17 \ --protocol-port 80 \ test-lb-pool-http #. You can use ``curl`` to verify connectivity through the load balancers to your web servers: .. code-block:: console $ curl 192.168.1.22 web2 $ curl 192.168.1.22 web1 $ curl 192.168.1.22 web2 $ curl 192.168.1.22 web1 In this example, the load balancer uses the round robin algorithm and the traffic alternates between the web servers on the backend. #. You can add a health monitor so that unresponsive servers are removed from the pool: .. code-block:: console $ neutron lbaas-healthmonitor-create \ --delay 5 \ --max-retries 2 \ --timeout 10 \ --type HTTP \ --pool test-lb-pool-http In this example, the health monitor removes the server from the pool if it fails a health check at two five-second intervals. When the server recovers and begins responding to health checks again, it is added to the pool once again. Adding an HTTPS listener ------------------------ You can add another listener on port 443 for HTTPS traffic. LBaaS v2 offers SSL/TLS termination at the load balancer, but this example takes a simpler approach and allows encrypted connections to terminate at each member server. #. Start by creating a listener, attaching a pool, and then adding members: .. code-block:: console $ neutron lbaas-listener-create \ --name test-lb-https \ --loadbalancer test-lb \ --protocol HTTPS \ --protocol-port 443 $ neutron lbaas-pool-create \ --name test-lb-pool-https \ --lb-algorithm LEAST_CONNECTIONS \ --listener test-lb-https \ --protocol HTTPS $ neutron lbaas-member-create \ --subnet private-subnet \ --address 192.168.1.16 \ --protocol-port 443 \ test-lb-pool-https $ neutron lbaas-member-create \ --subnet private-subnet \ --address 192.168.1.17 \ --protocol-port 443 \ test-lb-pool-https #. You can also add a health monitor for the HTTPS pool: .. code-block:: console $ neutron lbaas-healthmonitor-create \ --delay 5 \ --max-retries 2 \ --timeout 10 \ --type HTTPS \ --pool test-lb-pool-https The load balancer now handles traffic on ports 80 and 443. Associating a floating IP address --------------------------------- Load balancers that are deployed on a public or provider network that are accessible to external clients do not need a floating IP address assigned. External clients can directly access the virtual IP address (VIP) of those load balancers. However, load balancers deployed onto private or isolated networks need a floating IP address assigned if they must be accessible to external clients. To complete this step, you must have a router between the private and public networks and an available floating IP address. You can use the ``lbaas-loadbalancer-show`` command from the beginning of this section to locate the ``vip_port_id``. The ``vip_port_id`` is the ID of the network port that is assigned to the load balancer. You can associate a free floating IP address to the load balancer using ``floatingip-associate``: .. code-block:: console $ neutron floatingip-associate FLOATINGIP_ID LOAD_BALANCER_PORT_ID

commit_message:
Removing version from setup.cfg

pbr [1] does postversioning as part of packging,
so there is no need for us to specify a version
in metadata of setup.cfg

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/pbr/

Change-Id: I90d13777bcee53a7231f1012f1ae7bbccd63f12e
Closes-Bug: #1555712

* Add service_name parameter in ::nova::api with unit testing.
* Add apache module to fixtures for unit testing.
* Add apache module to metadata.json.
* Add WSGI paths to ::nova::params.
* Create ::nova::wsgi::apache with unit testing.
* Create acceptance tests to validate the transition from eventlet to
  WSGI.

Use-cases supported & limitations:
* All API (ec2, compute, metadata) running in eventlet. 100% backward
  compatible.
* ec2 and compute can be run in WSGI. In that case, if metadata is not
  in 'enabled_apis', nova-api won't be started, since everything will
  run in Apache. Also, if running WSGI, ec2 & compute will be run in
  WSGI. It's not possible to run one in eventlet, and one in WSGI. Though
  it's possible to enable only one of both.

This is a first implementation that keeps the deployment simple &
backward compatible.

Change-Id: I3a7c6af2d81da28e41ee278f11937364536efd9e

* Add service_name parameter in ::nova::api with unit testing covering
  use cases.
* Add apache module to fixtures for unit testing.
* Add apache module to metadata.json.
* Add WSGI paths to ::nova::params.
* Create ::nova::wsgi::apache with unit testing covering use cases.
* Create acceptance tests to validate the transition from eventlet to
  WSGI and make sure apache is stopped in eventlet testing.
* Create examples/nova_wsgi.pp to document use cases.

Use-cases supported & limitations:
* All API (ec2, compute, metadata) running in eventlet and 100% backward
  compatible.
* ec2 and compute can be run in WSGI. In that case, if metadata is not
  in 'enabled_apis', nova-api won't be started, since everything will
  run in Apache. Also, if running WSGI, ec2 & compute will be run in
  WSGI. It's not possible to run one in eventlet, and one in WSGI. Though
  it's possible to enable only one of both.

This is a first implementation that keeps the deployment simple &
backward compatible.

Change-Id: I3a7c6af2d81da28e41ee278f11937364536efd9e
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-09-17 15:13:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/70a58aa8fb65da56d13a83e9e1947da1535f501c', 'message': "Implement WSGI support for Nova API

* Add service_name parameter in ::nova::api with unit testing covering
  use cases.
* Add apache module to fixtures for unit testing.
* Add apache module to metadata.json.
* Add WSGI paths to ::nova::params.
* Create ::nova::wsgi::apache with unit testing covering use cases.
* Create acceptance tests to validate the transition from eventlet to
  WSGI and make sure apache is stopped in eventlet testing.
* Create examples/nova_wsgi.pp to document use cases.
* Deprecate enabled_apis as a string, to be an array later (with unit
  tests).

Use-cases supported & limitations:
* All API (ec2, compute, metadata) running in eventlet and 100% backward
  compatible.
* ec2 and compute can be run in WSGI. In that case, if metadata is not
  in 'enabled_apis', nova-api won't be started, since everything will
  run in Apache. Also, if running WSGI, ec2 & compute will be run in
  WSGI. It's not possible to run one in eventlet, and one in WSGI. Though
  it's possible to enable only one of both.

This is a first implementation that keeps the deployment simple &
backward compatible.
During this cycle, we accept enabled_apis as a string, but in Mitaka, we
will make sure it's an array so we can drop all the code that sanitize
the parameter to make sure we enable the right WSGI process.

Change-Id: I3a7c6af2d81da28e41ee278f11937364536efd9e

* Create ::nova::wsgi::apache with unit testing covering use cases.
* Create acceptance tests to validate the transition from eventlet to
  WSGI and make sure apache is stopped in eventlet testing.
* Create examples/nova_wsgi.pp to document use cases.
* Deprecate enabled_apis as a string, to be an array later (with unit
  tests).
* Drop eventlet testing

Use-cases supported & limitations:
* All API (compute, metadata) running in eventlet and 100% backward
  compatible.

This is a first implementation that keeps the deployment simple &
backward compatible.
During this cycle, we accept enabled_apis as a string, but in N cycle, we
will make sure it's an array so we can drop all the code that sanitize
the parameter to make sure we enable the right WSGI process.

Change-Id: I3a7c6af2d81da28e41ee278f11937364536efd9e

commit_message:
Implement WSGI support for Nova API

* Add service_name parameter in ::nova::api with unit testing covering
  use cases.
* Add apache module to fixtures for unit testing.
* Add apache module to metadata.json.
* Add WSGI paths to ::nova::params.
* Create ::nova::wsgi::apache with unit testing covering use cases.
* Create acceptance tests to validate the transition from eventlet to
  WSGI and make sure apache is stopped in eventlet testing.
* Create examples/nova_wsgi.pp to document use cases.
* Deprecate enabled_apis as a string, to be an array later (with unit
  tests).
* Drop eventlet testing

Use-cases supported & limitations:
* All API (compute, metadata) running in eventlet and 100% backward
  compatible.

This is a first implementation that keeps the deployment simple &
backward compatible.
During this cycle, we accept enabled_apis as a string, but in N cycle, we
will make sure it's an array so we can drop all the code that sanitize
the parameter to make sure we enable the right WSGI process.

Change-Id: I3a7c6af2d81da28e41ee278f11937364536efd9e

commit_message:
Revert "run keystone in a wsgi process"

This reverts commit 3c21196b3851283cf1ae2ed611f171c3da80e6a0.

The commit is breaking upgrades from kilo to liberty. Apparently the migration from keystone eventlet to keystone httpd is not cleanly handled.

Change-Id: I419bcb5c57008d6dde046f4f276857af5bcf70b6

commit_message:
Add the Angular LBaaS V2 'Update Member List' Table Action

This change adds the Update Member list table action to the pool members
table.  This wizard allows you to Add or Remove members from the current list
of members associated with a particular pool.

Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-lbaas-v2-ui
Change-Id: I640fdf2597e4a16191dbce8c20450c7c0dc882f0

added_lines: case 'createmembers': promise = $q.all([ neutronAPI.getSubnets().then(onGetSubnets).then(getMembers).then(onGetMembers), neutronAPI.getPorts().then(onGetPorts), novaAPI.getServers().then(onGetServers) ]).then(initMemberAddresses); model.context.submit = updatePoolMemberList; break; function updatePoolMemberList(spec) { console.log('here'); return lbaasv2API.updateMemberList(model.spec.parentResourceId, spec); } function onGetMembers(response) { setMembersSpec(response.data.items); } function getMembers() { return lbaasv2API.getMembers(model.spec.parentResourceId); }

commit_message:
Updated the events definitions.

The goal is to aggregate all the instance identifiers into the
event variable 'resource_id'

Change-Id: Iadfd0aab28f4d33438bcc9ee5af84fe4c7bdf0a7

added_lines: - event_type: scheduler.* traits: resource_id: fields: payload.request_spec.instance_properties.uuid - event_type: compute_task.* traits: resource_id: fields: payload.instance_id resource_id: exception_code: fields: payload.exception.exit_code exception_command: fields: payload.exception.cmd exception_description: fields: ['payload.exception.description', 'payload.exception.stderr']

commit_message:
Support Network Aggregate Metrics for Instance

Currently, we have metrics for instance's per vnic, but don't
have aggregate metrics, this patch adds those aggregate metrics
for each instance.

Document for Ceilometer mearsurements should be updated in OpenStack
Manual.

DocImpact
Implements blueprint instance-network-aggregate-metrics
Change-Id: I474620e7286c4e0ceb8d867f05e13fe417863022

commit_message:
return useful message when database is not available

Currently, as long as there is one alive database for alarm, event
or metering, we can start ceilometer-api. But when user requests
related API, he may get error message like:
'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get_event_types'.
Only when storage backend is mysql or postgresql, user will get
correct message that database cannot be connected.

With this patch, user will get precise information indicating that
corresponding backend is not available.

Change-Id: If7538a4d5e927006b6a8ae11b32950589fa61582
Closes-Bug: #1496830

commit_message:
Initial lite-specs.rst and per deliverable folders

Moving Glance Lite Specs from being tracked as WISHLIST bugs
and creating subfolders for each deliverable for appropriate
tracking of specs.

Initial lite-specs.rst and template for each deliverable.

specs/lite-specs.rst is included only to be a template, not
to include in any toctree.

Change-Id: I5f552cede83e6a204c3e469a08b685f1070daab9

commit_message:
Batch recording metering data to gnocchi

Now ceilometer makes many requests to record
metering data to gnocchi. This patch adds
possibility to speed up this process.

In this patch added function for batch request
for recording metering data to gnocchi.

[WIP]

Change-Id: I94aa38bcbc0a2f856501de19a25aed68fa0a0e4a
