added_lines: from ceilometer.i18n import _, _LW self.metric_map = self._build_metric_map() def _build_metric_map(self): metric_map = {} for ext in self.mgmr: for metric in ext.obj.get_metrics_names(): if (metric in metric_map and metric_map[metric] != ext): LOG.warn(_LW("There are more than one manager with equal " "metric %s") % metric) metric_map[metric] = ext return metric_map def record_batch_metering_data(self, data): data = [s for s in data if not self._is_gnocchi_activity(s)] resource_grouped_samples = {} for sample in data: if sample['counter_name'] in self.metric_map: resource_grouped_samples.setdefault( sample['resource_id'], {}) meter = resource_grouped_samples[sample['resource_id']] meter.setdefault(sample['counter_name'], []) meter[sample['counter_name']].append(sample) prepared_data = [] for resource in six.itervalues(resource_grouped_samples): prepared_resources = {} for metric, samples in six.iteritems(resource): metric_params = {metric: self.get_archive_policy(metric)} measure_attributes = [{'timestamp': sample['timestamp'], 'value': sample['counter_volume']} for sample in samples] metric_params[metric]['measures'] = measure_attributes if self.metric_map[metric] in prepared_resources: prepared_resource = prepared_resources[ self.metric_map[metric]] prepared_resource['metrics'][metric].update(metric_params) else: ext = self.metric_map[metric] sample = samples[-1] prepared_resource = ext.obj.get_resource_extra_attributes( sample) prepared_resource['metrics'] = metric_params prepared_resource["id"] = sample['resource_id'] prepared_resource["user_id"] = sample['user_id'] prepared_resource["project_id"] = sample['project_id'] prepared_resource['resource_type'] = ext.name prepared_resources[ext] = prepared_resource prepared_data.extend(six.itervalues(prepared_resources)) self.gnocchi_api.post("%s/v1/resource" % (self.gnocchi_url), headers=self._get_headers(), data=json.dumps(prepared_data))

commit_message:
Use consistent type checking of project_id in API

We were using inconsistent type checking for the project_id in various
API endpoints. This could lead to erratic behavior if some API requests
specified the project_id UUID with hyphens and some without hyphens and
normlization occurred.

This patch changes this behavior to use consistent type checking for the
project_id for all API endpoints. Since this bug is a regression that is
less than 2 weeks old, I've also introduced a few unit tests which
should ensure we don't have another regression of the desired behavior
anytime soon.

Change-Id: I4c3ec52c01547196160e977029ecc5ded97c79ed
Closes-Bug: #1555401
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/36/290936/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use auth plugins for keystoneclient

Construct and use auth plugins for keystoneclient rather than passing
all options to the client. This is a step towards making auth plugins
interchangeable and supporting v3 authentication.

Note that this is not the most efficient way to use a plugin but matches
the current behaviour.

Change-Id: I782c450a26be8a894428fae23d3ab071a8e383d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/43/213943/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: LVM: Support a volume-gorup on shared storage
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-06 19:12:01.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/test_utils.py', 'cinder/brick/initiator/connector.py', 'cinder/tests/test_volume.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/e1692084420431f8b7adbcfd08febc5f90002ad5', 'message': 'LVM: Support a volume-gorup on shared storage

Currently LVM driver uses software iSCSI target to export a
volume-group. This patch adds a feature to support a volume-group on
shared storage instead of exporting via iSCSI target. When a
volume-group on a shared storage (over fibre, iscsi or whatever) is
visible from all nodes such as a cinder node and compute nodes, these
nodes can access the volume-group simultaneously without the target.

General benefits
- Enable cinder to any kinds of shared storages without specific cinder
  driver.
- In regard to one storage, use both specific cinder driver and cinder
  shared LVM driver as the situation demands.
- Provide quicker volume and snapshot creation.

*Note that this requires a Nova libvirt LibvirtSharedLvmDriver as well.
 - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage
 - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

Change-Id: I92ef1ae77c3f297abce7801909f69c907ecb0eb4
Signed-off-by: Mitsuhiro Tanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com>
Implements: blueprint lvm-driver-for-shared-storage
'}]
commit_message:
LVM: Support a volume-gorup on shared storage

Currently LVM driver uses software iSCSI target to export a
volume-group. This patch adds a feature to support a volume-group on
shared storage instead of exporting via iSCSI target. When a
volume-group on a shared storage (over fibre, iscsi or whatever) is
visible from all nodes such as a cinder node and compute nodes, these
nodes can access the volume-group simultaneously without the target.

General benefits
- Enable cinder to any kinds of shared storages without specific cinder
  driver.
- In regard to one storage, use both specific cinder driver and cinder
  shared LVM driver as the situation demands.
- Provide quicker volume and snapshot creation.

*Note that this requires a Nova libvirt LibvirtSharedLvmDriver as well.
 - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage
 - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/lvm-driver-for-shared-storage

Change-Id: I92ef1ae77c3f297abce7801909f69c907ecb0eb4
Signed-off-by: Mitsuhiro Tanino <mitsuhiro.tanino@hds.com>
Implements: blueprint lvm-driver-for-shared-storage
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/37/92437/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class SharedLVMDriver(LVMVolumeDriver, driver.VolumeDriver): """Executes commands relating to LVM on muliple attached volume. """ def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(SharedLVMDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.backend_name =\ self.configuration.safe_get('volume_backend_name') or 'LVM_MATTACH' self.protocol = 'lvm' def ensure_export(self, context, volume): """Driver entry point to get the export info for an existing volume.""" pass def _create_export(self, context, volume, vg=None): """Driver entry point to get the export info for a new volume.""" pass def create_export(self, context, volume): """Driver entry point to get the export info for a new volume.""" pass def remove_export(self, context, volume): """Driver entry point to remove an export for a volume.""" pass def _get_lvm_properties(self, volume): """Get lvm configuration The properties are: :volume_id: the id of the volume. :volume_path: the device path to access the logical volume. :access_mode: the volume access mode allow client used. ('rw' or 'ro' currently supported) """ LOG.debug(_('_get_lvm_properties')) vg = self.configuration.volume_group properties = { 'volume_id': volume['id'], 'volume_path': "/dev/%s/%s" % (vg, volume['name']), 'access_mode': 'rw' } return properties def initialize_connection(self, volume, connector): """Initializes the connection and returns connection info. The lvm driver returns a driver_volume_type of 'lvm'. The format of the driver data is defined in _get_lvm_properties. Example return value:: { 'driver_volume_type': 'lvm' 'data': { 'volume_id' : '61d14def-18ac-43ff-abdf-67d1d36cf9bf', 'volume_path': '/dev/volume group/volume_id', 'access_mode': 'rw' } } """ LOG.debug(_('Initialize_connection')) lvm_properties = self._get_lvm_properties(volume) LOG.debug(_("volume_id: %s") % lvm_properties['volume_id']) LOG.debug(_("volume_path: %s") % lvm_properties['volume_path']) LOG.debug(_("access_mode: %s") % lvm_properties['access_mode']) return { 'driver_volume_type': 'lvm', 'data': lvm_properties } def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs): pass def migrate_volume(self, ctxt, volume, host, thin=False, mirror_count=0): """Optimize the migration if the destination is on the same server. If the specified host is another back-end on the same server, and the volume is not attached, we can do the migration locally without going through iSCSI. """ false_ret = (False, None) if volume['status'] != 'available': return false_ret LOG.debug(_("migrate_volume volume['status']=%s") % volume['status']) if 'location_info' not in host['capabilities']: return false_ret LOG.debug(_("migrate_volume host['capabilities']['location_info']=%s") % host['capabilities']['location_info']) info = host['capabilities']['location_info'] try: (dest_type, dest_hostname, dest_vg, lvm_type, lvm_mirrors) =\ info.split(':') lvm_mirrors = int(lvm_mirrors) except ValueError: return false_ret LOG.debug(_("migrate_volume dest_type=%(dest_type)s," "dest_hostname=%(dest_hostname,)s," "dest_vg=%(dest_vg)s") % dest_type, dest_hostname, dest_vg) if (dest_type != 'LVMVolumeDriver'): return false_ret LOG.debug(_("migrate_volume dest_vg=%(dest_vg,)s," "self.vg.vg_name=%(self.vg.vg_name)s") % dest_vg, self.vg.vg_name) if dest_vg != self.vg.vg_name: vg_list = volutils.get_all_volume_groups() try: (vg for vg in vg_list if vg['name'] == dest_vg).next() except StopIteration: message = ("Destination Volume Group %s does not exist" % dest_vg) LOG.error(_('%s'), message) return false_ret helper = utils.get_root_helper() dest_vg_ref = lvm.LVM(dest_vg, helper, lvm_type=lvm_type, executor=self._execute) self.remove_export(ctxt, volume) self._create_volume(volume['name'], self._sizestr(volume['size']), lvm_type, lvm_mirrors, dest_vg_ref) volutils.copy_volume(self.local_path(volume), self.local_path(volume, vg=dest_vg), volume['size'], self.configuration.volume_dd_blocksize, execute=self._execute) self._delete_volume(volume) model_update = self._create_export(ctxt, volume, vg=dest_vg) return (True, model_update)

subject: Add capabilities filter for Nova
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-10 01:56:59.000000000', 'files': ['tripleo_common/tests/fake_nova/__init__.py', 'tripleo_common/filters/__init__.py', 'tripleo_common/tests/fake_nova/scheduler/__init__.py', 'tripleo_common/tests/fake_nova/scheduler/filters.py', 'tripleo_common/tests/test_filters.py', 'tripleo_common/filters/capabilities_filter.py', 'tripleo_common/tests/fake_nova/README', 'tripleo_common/filters/list.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/4685a0b5bd324ff12e0c237f735426511fb9680e', 'message': "Add capabilities filter for Nova

It turns out that the ComputeCapabilitiesFilter built-in to Nova
doesn't respect capabilities passed in scheduler_hints, so we can't
use it for predictable placement.  Adding this filter to the
undercloud Nova filter list will allow us to do so.

Instead of pulling in all of Nova as a test requirement, I've added
a fake_nova module to the source tree, which is injected as 'nova'
when unit tests are being run.  A check is included to make sure
nova isn't being imported for real, as well as a README explaining
the reasoning behind the fake_nova module.

Change-Id: I0618a3b9e3c33af7cdc78db4b6994d463b8aeda9
(cherry picked from commit f1c6ac9f2eb05064fca1cb7a92148b96068ed251)
"}]
commit_message:
Add capabilities filter for Nova

It turns out that the ComputeCapabilitiesFilter built-in to Nova
doesn't respect capabilities passed in scheduler_hints, so we can't
use it for predictable placement.  Adding this filter to the
undercloud Nova filter list will allow us to do so.

Instead of pulling in all of Nova as a test requirement, I've added
a fake_nova module to the source tree, which is injected as 'nova'
when unit tests are being run.  A check is included to make sure
nova isn't being imported for real, as well as a README explaining
the reasoning behind the fake_nova module.

Change-Id: I0618a3b9e3c33af7cdc78db4b6994d463b8aeda9
(cherry picked from commit f1c6ac9f2eb05064fca1cb7a92148b96068ed251)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/42/290942/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import nova from tripleo_common.filters import capabilities_filter def tripleo_filters(): """Return a list of filter classes for TripleO This is a wrapper around the Nova all_filters function so we can add our filters to the resulting list. """ nova_filters = nova.scheduler.filters.all_filters() return (nova_filters + [capabilities_filter.TripleOCapabilitiesFilter])

Add initial spec for os-testr

* Re-written using new syntax
* Add lower bounds according to requirements
* Add docs

commit_message:
Add complex query for statistic requests

Currenly in statistics request we use only simple queries.
It allows only queries with one value of filtered field.
One `resource_id` or `project_id` by query.
Otherwise the current implementation of Horizon Metering Dashboard
makes one request for every resource in new thread for creating statistics
chart. This behavior bulk the ceilometer backend with heavy process and may
be changed to one request with more flexible query.

Also we want to add ability to collect statistics by complex rules.

This CR adds complex query endpoint for statistics.
For mongodb added function that allows to work with complex query
for statistics. For this changes added tests. In next patch set the same
function will be made for mysql.

This CR may improve user experience and simplify current UI implementation.

Change-Id: Ib0c963fd8370792ec3ccb9a120c6306165976dab

added_lines: from ceilometer.api.controllers.v2 import metersclass ComplexStatisticsQuery(base.Base): filter = wtypes.text "The filter expression encoded in json." period = int "The difference, in seconds, between the period start and end" groupby = wtypes.ArrayType(wtypes.text) "Dictionary of field names for group, if groupby statistics are requested" aggregate = wtypes.ArrayType(meters.Aggregate) "The selectable aggregate value(s)" @classmethod def sample(cls): return cls(filter='{"and": [{"and": [{"=": ' + '{"counter_name": "cpu_util"}}, ' + '{">": {"counter_volume": 0.23}}, ' + '{"<": {"counter_volume": 0.26}}]}, ' + '{"or": [{"and": [{">": ' + '{"timestamp": "2013-12-01T18:00:00"}}, ' + '{"<": ' + '{"timestamp": "2013-12-01T18:15:00"}}]}, ' + '{"and": [{">": ' + '{"timestamp": "2013-12-01T18:30:00"}}, ' + '{"<": ' + '{"timestamp": "2013-12-01T18:45:00"}}]}]}]}', period=60, groupby=["project_id"] ) def _validate(self, visibility_field): def validate(self, visibility_field): self._validate(visibility_field) class ValidatedComplexStatisticsQuery(ValidatedComplexQuery): def validate(self, visibility_field): self._validate(visibility_field) if self.original_query.period is wtypes.Unset: self.period = None else: self.period = self.original_query.period if self.original_query.groupby is wtypes.Unset: self.groupby = [] else: self.groupby = self.original_query.groupby if self.original_query.aggregate is wtypes.Unset: self.aggregate = [] else: self.aggregate = self.original_query.aggregate self.aggregate = utils.uniq(self.aggregate, ['func', 'param']) class QueryStatisticsController(rest.RestController): """Provides complex query possibilities for samples.""" @wsme_pecan.wsexpose([meters.Statistics], body=ComplexStatisticsQuery) def post(self, body): """Define query for retrieving Statistics data. :param body: Query rules for the samples to be returned. """ rbac.enforce('query_sample', pecan.request) sample_name_mapping = {"resource": "resource_id", "meter": "counter_name", "type": "counter_type", "unit": "counter_unit", "volume": "counter_volume"} query = ValidatedComplexStatisticsQuery(body, storage.models.Sample, sample_name_mapping) query.validate(visibility_field="project_id") conn = pecan.request.storage_conn return [meters.Statistics.from_db_model(s) for s in conn.query_statistics(query.filter_expr, query.period, query.groupby, query.aggregate)] statistics = QueryStatisticsController()

added_lines: # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0from ceilometer.agent.discovery import localnode from ceilometer.agent.discovery import tenant from ceilometer.i18n import _LW @mock.patch('ceilometer.agent.discovery.endpoint.LOG') def test_no_endpoints(self, log): self.manager.keystone.service_catalog.get_urls = mock.MagicMock() self.manager.keystone.service_catalog.get_urls.return_value = None ret = self.discovery.discover(self.manager) self.assertEqual([], ret) log.warning.assert_called_with(_LW('No endpoints found for service ' '%s'), "<all services>") class TestLocalNodeDiscovery(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestLocalNodeDiscovery, self).setUp() self.discovery = localnode.LocalNodeDiscovery() self.manager = mock.MagicMock() def test_return_local_host(self): ret = self.discovery.discover(self.manager) self.assertEqual(['local_host'], ret) class TestTenantDiscovery(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestTenantDiscovery, self).setUp() self.discovery = tenant.TenantDiscovery() self.manager = mock.MagicMock() self.manager.keystone.tenants.list = mock.MagicMock() def test_return_tenants(self): tenants = [mock.MagicMock()] self.manager.keystone.tenants.list.return_value = tenants ret = self.discovery.discover(self.manager) self.assertEqual(tenants, ret) def test_return_empty_array_of_tenants(self): self.manager.keystone.tenants.list.return_value = None ret = self.discovery.discover(self.manager) self.assertEqual([], ret)

commit_message:
Start shift to symbol nomenclature

Instead of referring to argument mappings and result
mappings names just refer to these as (unbound) symbols
required by atoms that are produced by atoms as (bound)
symbols which are later consumed by other atoms.

To start the transition to those concepts adjust some
of the comments, method names and strings to use the
more commonly understood symbol definitions instead of
the prior convention.

Once completed this nomenclature shift will create a more
unified set of terms and terminology that can be used throughout
taskflow to make it easier to understand the comments, docs,
examples and code...

Part of blueprint nomenclature-using-symbols

Change-Id: I15515c84ae39f001724c0598fcf2606a508bb0b9

commit_message:
Add a symbol type (WIP)

A symbol type will be useful for more advanced operation on
input and output symbols and allows for providing the symbols
that identify dependencies to also carry attributes which we can
use to infer additional logic/capabilities of those symbols.

Change-Id: I6968cfb078e8be27b41f96341708b1ba8e86fe42

added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright (C) 2015 Yahoo! Inc. All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo.utils import reflection import six class Symbol(object): """A named symbol that may contain useful attributes about itself.""" def __init__(self, name, **kwargs): self._name = name self._attributes = kwargs @property def attributes(self): return self._attributes def __hash__(self): return hash((self._name,)) def __str__(self): return self._name def copy(self): t = type(self) return t(self._name, **self._attributes) def __repr__(self): blob = "%s object '%s' at 0x%x" % (reflection.get_class_name(self), self._name, id(self)) blob += " with attributes %s" % (self._attributes) return "<%s>" % blob def __eq__(self, other): """Checks for string or symbol equality. When symbol equality is performed attributes are currently ignored... """ if isinstance(other, six.string_types): return other == self._name elif isinstance(other, Symbol): return other._name == self._name else: return NotImplemented

added_lines: Notification agents may run in HA mode. The configuration option ``workload_partitioning`` should be enabled for this purpose. When running multiple agents we need to deal with two queues: main queue which accepts messages from OpenStack components and pipeline queue - the queue for inter process communication (IPC). After receiving from the main queue, messages are processed by corresponding plugins (endpoints) as described earlier (including filtering). All of endpoints are served by a manager which knows what notifier should be used for publishing, i.e. what topic name should be used during IPC. After receiving from pipeline queue messages are processed with only one plugin: EventPipelineEndpoint or SamplePipelineEndpoint. The load is distributed on the last stage: receiving data from IPC queue. Each agent asks Partition Coordinator to provide a set of pipes to serve, i.e. set of topics to listen to. .. The source for the following diagram can be found at: https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1JEf4iJSjCIUAEvKQi2hEfCD7xaNCBbqhqQF5pC-OsGk/edit?usp=sharing .. figure:: ./coordination-notification-agents.png :width: 100% :align: center :alt: Architecture summary

commit_message:
Indexes changes in mongodb

In resource get_all request result resources are sorted
descending by user id, project id and last sample timestamp id.
But if we have too much data in resources collection we
will get the error. So we need compound index in resource
collection.
Sources are dropped because they are not used.

Change-Id: I9e02e6e61234b862ce4bf0b62fea72d8d061579e
Partial-Bug: #1433924

commit_message:
Separates event listener from sample listener

As many listeners were created as number of
messaging_urls. When the sample pipeline is
refreshed, the listeners are restarted, thus
interrupting both sample and event consumption.

This fix separates event listener from sample
listener, so that a refresh of a pipeline results
in restart of only the specific listener that uses
the refreshed pipeline.

Change-Id: I5551f71ac33478bca5fff5fd3a99e520fd79fbd7
Closes-Bug: 1477321

commit_message:
Fix database purge query

Fix raw_template purge query on MySQL, and handle stack tags before
removing stacks. This also removes a bunch of race conditions where we
deleted incorrect data.

Change-Id: I7b7a1d94acefbaeeed86f1833c979819361c8988
Closes-Bug: #1524387
(cherry picked from commit 6cece5bb7e9e10dfb33596c32319e7ad9b81fbff)

commit_message:
Query statistics function for sql

In previous patch in the chain was created query statistics
controller with mongodb fuction for processing complex
statistics queries.

In this patch was added enother one function for processing
statistics complex queries. It function works with sql
databases.

Change-Id: I6812e4e0316cf85696238093b230e1cef641a825

commit_message:
Fix the doc about swift middleware configuration

Change-Id: Ie3c1ba4652daeda5dea164c0d218d610c9ccfa10
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/11/193111/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: You'll also need to add the Ceilometer middleware to Swift to account for incoming and outgoing traffic notifications. In ``/etc/swift/proxy-server.conf`` on the main pipeline add ``ceilometer`` just before ``proxy-server``. Besides, add the following filter in the same the file:: [filter:ceilometer] paste.filter_factory = ceilometermiddleware.swift:filter_factory # Allow to publish additional metadata metadata_headers = X-TEST # Set reseller prefix (defaults to "AUTH_" if not set) reseller_prefix = AUTH_ # Set control_exchange to publish to control_exchange = swift # Set transport url url = rabbit://me:passwd@host:5672/virtual_host # set messaging driver driver = messaging # set topic topic = notifications
deleted_lines: You'll also need to add the Ceilometer middleware to Swift to account for incoming and outgoing traffic, by adding these lines to ``/etc/swift/proxy-server.conf``:: [filter:ceilometer] use = egg:ceilometer#swift And adding ``ceilometer`` in the ``pipeline`` of that same file, right before ``proxy-server``. Additionally, if you want to store extra metadata from headers, you need to set ``metadata_headers`` so it would look like:: [filter:ceilometer] use = egg:ceilometer#swift metadata_headers = X-FOO, X-BAR

commit_message:
Remove an unused method in FakeResourceTracker

Nothing calls _create and there is no _create in the super class for
this to be overriding.

commit_message:
Samples with last timestamp in sqlalchemy backend

Samples with last timestamp are excluded from statistics output
when last period end equals timestamp end. This patch fix this
problem.

Change-Id: Ic97118fbf1747de7812b5c8b919ad9809a34c475
Closes-Bug: #1463368

commit_message:
Allow admin_url to be configured independently of internal

Some administrators want to configure the management endpoint to be on a
separate interface to the internal address. This change adds a separate
variable for the admin_address, defaulting to the internal_address to
preserve existing behaviour.

Change-Id: Ida5ac5bb444183db0a1b5f502b3ba336ef492512
Closes-Bug: #1535333

commit_message:
[Ironic]Match vif-pif mac address before setting 'vif_port_id'

When booting an ironic instance with multi networks, the ironic port
'vif_port_id' may mismatch with the corresponding neutron port.

Closes-Bug: #1549068
Co-Authored-By: Sivaramakrishna Garimella (sivaramakrishna.garimella@hp.com)

Change-Id: Id5f033136283987eef8de4ce2f6be256e48cdbf8
(cherry picked from commit e147a63cb396ebaadd7c841a305cf3a52be1d373)

subject: Cap cliff-tablib <2.0 in stable/kilo
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-26 10:40:03.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/1040ff958015c2326ccaf102885ad2c1453803e2', 'message': 'Cap cliff-tablib <2.0 in stable/kilo

cliff-tablib 2.0 which drops JSON/YAML formatters was released
to avoid duplicated JSON formatter problem in cliff >=1.15.0 and
cliff-tablib (bug 1531574).

Kilo uses cliff<1.11.0,>=1.10.0 and in this version of cliff JSON/YAML
formatters are provided by cliff-tablib. If cliff-tablib 2.0 is used,
users cannot use JSON and YAML formatters (bug 1538044).
To deal with this problem, we need to cap cliff-tablib to <2.0.

cliff-tablib 1.1 is used in upper-constraints.txt, so there is
no change required.

This affects Kilo version of cliff-based pythonclient including
python-neutronclient and python-openstackclient.
Note that this does not affect Liberty and Mitaka.

Change-Id: I4954188c24517642a4d57db389c0511b32a0a095
Closes-Bug: #1538044
Related-Bug: #1531574
'}]
commit_message:
Cap cliff-tablib <2.0 in stable/kilo

cliff-tablib 2.0 which drops JSON/YAML formatters was released
to avoid duplicated JSON formatter problem in cliff >=1.15.0 and
cliff-tablib (bug 1531574).

Kilo uses cliff<1.11.0,>=1.10.0 and in this version of cliff JSON/YAML
formatters are provided by cliff-tablib. If cliff-tablib 2.0 is used,
users cannot use JSON and YAML formatters (bug 1538044).
To deal with this problem, we need to cap cliff-tablib to <2.0.

cliff-tablib 1.1 is used in upper-constraints.txt, so there is
no change required.

This affects Kilo version of cliff-based pythonclient including
python-neutronclient and python-openstackclient.
Note that this does not affect Liberty and Mitaka.

Change-Id: I4954188c24517642a4d57db389c0511b32a0a095
Closes-Bug: #1538044
Related-Bug: #1531574
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/57/272457/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cliff-tablib>=1.0,<2.0

commit_message:
Check alarm periods to the granularities

This patch adds check that evaluation_periods for alarm matches
with granulary of metric(s) that uses for this alarm.

Change-Id: Ida485f80facb6d9f77446f3a746ff02a9f1fc771
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/71/164171/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from pytimeparse import timeparseimport six def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(AlarmGnocchiThresholdRule, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.gnocchi_url = cfg.CONF.alarms.gnocchi_url self._ks_client = keystone_client.get_client() def _get_headers(self, content_type="application/json"): return { 'Content-Type': content_type, 'X-Auth-Token': self._ks_client.auth_token, } try: uuid.UUID(rule.resource_constraint) url = ("%s/v1/resource/%s/%s") % (rule.gnocchi_url, rule.resource_type, rule.resource_constraint) except ValueError: url = ("%s/v1/resource/%s?%s") % (rule.gnocchi_url, rule.resource_type, rule.resource_constraint) try: r = requests.get(url, headers=rule._get_headers()) except Exception: raise try: fields = jsonutils.loads(r.text) if not isinstance(fields, list): fields = [fields] except Exception: raise Exception("Error with parsing response from metric.") for resource in fields: urlm = ("%s/v1/metric/%s?details=true") % ( rule.gnocchi_url, resource['metrics'][rule.metric]) try: rm = requests.get(urlm, headers=rule._get_headers()) except Exception: raise try: fieldsm = jsonutils.loads(rm.text) except Exception: raise Exception("Error with parsing response from metric.") for am in fieldsm['archive_policy']['definition']: seconds = timeparse.timeparse(six.text_type(am['granularity'])) if (rule.evaluation_periods % seconds == 0): return else: raise Exception( "Evaluation period doesn't matches with granularity.") @classmethod def validate_alarm(cls, alarm): rule = getattr(alarm, "%s_rule" % alarm.type) super(AlarmGnocchiMetricsThresholdRule, rule).validate_alarm(alarm) for m in rule.metrics: url = ("%s/v1/metric/%s?details=true") % (rule.gnocchi_url, m) try: r = requests.get(url, headers=rule._get_headers()) except Exception: raise try: fields = jsonutils.loads(r.text) except Exception: raise Exception("Error with parsing response.") for a in fields['archive_policy']['definition']: seconds = timeparse.timeparse(six.text_type(a['granularity'])) if (rule.evaluation_periods % seconds == 0): return else: raise Exception( "Evaluation period doesn't matches with granularity.")

commit_message:
Optimize sample list query

Modified to use subselect when
a limit number of samples are expected.

Change-Id: I098975d4000cab1affe9d42346422049b3386cf8
Closes-Bug: #1400476
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/77/139677/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: query = session.query(models.Sample.timestamp, models.Sample.recorded_at, models.Sample.message_id, models.Sample.message_signature, models.Sample.volume.label('counter_volume'), models.Meter.name.label('counter_name'), models.Meter.type.label('counter_type'), models.Meter.unit.label('counter_unit'), models.Resource.source_id, models.Resource.user_id, models.Resource.project_id, models.Resource.resource_metadata, models.Resource.resource_id).join( models.Meter, models.Meter.id == models.Sample.meter_id).join( models.Resource, models.Resource.internal_id == models.Sample.resource_id).order_by( models.Sample.timestamp.desc())

commit_message:
use precise marker function for log message translation

According to guidelines http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html
we can/should use _LI, _LW, _LE, _LC for different log level messages
to lower translation burden.

This patch adds hacking checks to follow i18n's guide, and fixes some
string interpolation issues for log messages.

Change-Id: Idcd4775e70b28279d4022451e70d9671c187846c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/54/148254/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: For log message translation issue, see guidelines: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html - [C301] Use _LC() for critical log level message translation - [C302] Use _LE() for exception log level message translation

commit_message:
Check triple double quotes are used in docstrings

Currently there are no check the rule:
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0257/:
For consistency, always use """triple double quotes"""
around docstrings. This patchset adds this check.

Change-Id: Ib1008ec1d0e4956f89bc661146a0ac2bb3e80b11
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/11/147211/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import hacking DOCSTRING_TRIPLE = ['u"""', 'r"""', '"""'] def check_double_quoted(physical_line, previous_logical, tokens): docstring = hacking.checks.docstrings.is_docstring(tokens, previous_logical) if docstring: valid_start = False valid_end = False for quotes in DOCSTRING_TRIPLE: if docstring.startswith(quotes): valid_start = True if docstring.endswith(quotes): valid_end = True if not valid_start or not valid_end: return (0, "Must be used double quoted.") register(check_double_quoted)

commit_message:
add metadata_updater transformer

There is a scenario that our end user wants to show resources/meters
by categories, for example, show resources/meters in Nova services.

It is hard to do it by using currect interfaces, because there is no
such field can be used.

Changing source of sample is one solution but needs to modify source
code and it is hard to meet different deployments.

This patch provides a way by configuring in pipeline to append or update
some metadata fields to samples, then we can request resources via query
field such as metadata.belong=nova to get some specific resources.

Change-Id: Ib0dc6116472b8fe2f4d2fe2a7e1b6fca8dfdd6af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/05/152505/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: metadata_appendor = ceilometer.transformer.conversions.MetadataTransformer

commit_message:
Correctly handle vmware performance query errors

When performance query for certain meter fails in vsphere, it reports
"-1" in the value. As a result, ceilometer will take -1 as the volume of
the meter, which is incorrect and misleading.

1, An exception will be raised when vm is not "active".
2, If one disk or one nic is error, the "-1" will be replaced by "0" so
that the total IO rates are not effected.
3, When cpu_util and memory.usage is error, an exception will be raised
and the sample will not be generated.

Closes-Bug: #1404192
Change-Id: I29d071b79d5b5a8d37f520b2209683ca249081a8

commit_message:
Use urlunparse to reconstruct base_url

Using string replace to replace the new path back onto the old path
fails when there is no path setup in the catalog initially. Instead of
this lets use the inverse to the urlparse previously performed.

Change-Id: I931f0c558aafc8dfaa5519744c6e4e7fcffc3205
Closes-Bug: #1552475

added_lines: _base_url = urlparse.urlunparse((parts.scheme, parts.netloc, path, parts.params, parts.query, parts.fragment))

commit_message:
Grab upper-constaints file for oslo master jobs

Looks like there were changes in the CI system which we
need to catch up with:
http://logs.openstack.org/periodic/periodic-nova-py27-with-oslo-master/bc1a2b8/console.html#_2016-03-10_06_04_18_695

Essentially, run-tox.sh sets the UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE
variable and the tox.ini of the projects uses it. We
need to make sure we fetch the file to where
UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE points to.

Change-Id: I48a75ab3b98ab439faf1479653280a8e683ef7bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/65/291165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make test cases test_crypto.py from NoDBTestCase

No need to access db for crypto test cases, this patch
mocked one db access and make all others inherit from
NoDBTestCase.

Change-Id: Ie8f49b7139a0a95bf39f3978af9cf3f992543b39

commit_message:
Set deprecated tasks.yaml file existence optional

Deprecated task.yaml file will not be used in future,
then remove check file exsistence as required option

Change-Id: Id8e738fc9b4680d52ef20d45ff7c16ed7b4e8145
Closes-Bug: 1552248

commit_message:
Add Database fixture to sync to a specific version

This makes it easier to do tests against a specific migration
with realistic data instead of mocking out all the important parts.

Change-Id: I3a635233c8f676b95fd4cf821123c69768e6dc37
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/48/289448/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_fixture_schema_version(self): self.useFixture(conf_fixture.ConfFixture()) # In/after 317 aggregates did have uuid self.useFixture(fixtures.Database(version=318)) engine = session.get_engine() engine.connect() meta = sqlalchemy.MetaData(engine) aggregate = sqlalchemy.Table('aggregates', meta, autoload=True) self.assertTrue(hasattr(aggregate.c, 'uuid')) # Before 317, aggregates had no uuid self.useFixture(fixtures.Database(version=316)) engine = session.get_engine() engine.connect() meta = sqlalchemy.MetaData(engine) aggregate = sqlalchemy.Table('aggregates', meta, autoload=True) self.assertFalse(hasattr(aggregate.c, 'uuid')) engine.dispose()

commit_message:
Record and check insertion time, rather than mocking

Some storage systems may record their own recorded_at timestamp,
which can't easily be mocked.  So, instead record the timestamp
on the client, and validate that recorded_at matches within a skew.

This might fail if running on a remote database with a mismatched time,
though we expect most unit tests to run on a single machine.

Change-Id: If4f252485e52873363550800a9a8ec5cf16f2770
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/59/119759/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.recorded_at = timeutils.utcnow() actual = timeutils.parse_isotime(s['recorded_at']) expected = self.recorded_at # Need to remove timezones for delta_seconds # (timeutils.utcnow() should really return tz=UTC) actual = timeutils.normalize_time(actual) expected = timeutils.normalize_time(expected) delta_seconds = timeutils.delta_seconds(expected, actual) # If this fails when running on a remote storage system, # verify that clocks are set consistently self.assertLessEqual(abs(delta_seconds), 30)
deleted_lines: import mock patcher = mock.patch.object(timeutils, 'utcnow') self.addCleanup(patcher.stop) self.mock_utcnow = patcher.start() self.mock_utcnow.return_value = datetime.datetime(2014, 2, 11, 16, 42) self.assertEqual(timeutils.utcnow().isoformat(), s['recorded_at'])

commit_message:
Don't setup ARP protection on OVS for network ports

Skip adding ARP spoofing protection on OVS ports with a
device_owner field starting with 'network:'. This is
already the case for the other iptables-based spoofing
protection and is necessary for floating IPs to function
correctly on router gateway ports.

Conflicts:
	neutron/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py
	neutron/tests/functional/agent/test_ovs_flows.py
	neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/test_ovs_neutron_agent.py

Closes-Bug: #1487338
Change-Id: I32cef17ff47fd62e6db16b9083104f07239be25f
(cherry picked from commit da1ac497d2d10d008925311e3f14e9750f7b86b2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/12/288612/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Cover impl_db2 by tests

Covered mongoDB version checking and and db
authentication in impl_db2 by tests.

Change-Id: Ied07e94d6f6f90dd08d8b63c06b5e3c84377dcad

conn_mock objectid.return_value = fake_str cfg.CONF.set_override('db2nosql_resource_id_maxlen', 512, group='database') self.assertRaises(storage.StorageBadVersion, impl_db2.Connection, 'db2://user:pwd@localhost:27017/ceilodb2') self.assertRaises(storage.StorageBadVersion, impl_db2_alarm.Connection, 'db2://user:pwd@localhost:27017/ceilodb2') self.assertRaises(storage.StorageBadVersion, impl_db2_event.Connection, 'db2://user:pwd@localhost:27017/ceilodb2') @mock.patch.object(pymongo_utils.ConnectionPool, 'connect') @mock.patch.object(bson.objectid, 'ObjectId') def test_authenticate_with_connection_options(self, objectid, mongo_connect): fake_str = '54b8860d75bfe43b54e84ce7' fake_db = mock.MagicMock() fake_db.authenticate = mock.MagicMock() conn_mock = mock.MagicMock() conn_mock.db = fake_db conn_mock.server_info.return_value = {} mongo_connect.return_value = conn_mock objectid.return_value = fake_str test_user_name = 'test_user' test_password = 'test_pass' cfg.CONF.set_override('db2nosql_resource_id_maxlen', 512, group='database') impl_db2.Connection('db2://%(name)s:%(pswd)s@localhost:27017/db' % { 'name': test_user_name, 'pswd': test_password }) fake_db.authenticate.assert_called_with(test_user_name, test_password) fake_db.authenticate.reset_mock() impl_db2_alarm.Connection('db2://%(name)s:%(pswd)s@localhost:27017/db' % {'name': test_user_name, 'pswd': test_password}) fake_db.authenticate.assert_called_with(test_user_name, test_password) fake_db.authenticate.reset_mock() impl_db2_event.Connection('db2://%(name)s:%(pswd)s@localhost:27017/db' % {'name': test_user_name, 'pswd': test_password}) fake_db.authenticate.assert_called_with(test_user_name, test_password)

commit_message:
Introduced command 'redeploy-changes'

The command 'redeploy-changes' allows to apply the changes
to the cluster which is in the operational state.
This allows you to deploy the changes without the
reprovisioning procedure.

Example: `fuel redeploy-changes --env <env_id>`

Partial-Bug: 1540558
Change-Id: Ida0c24075a3deeb1635f579ec00728434bc7a6d6
Depends-On: Ibc89fdbfbd0a36a890412cd8e861d35bcf930690

added_lines: Args.get_force_arg("Deploy changes forcefully."), deploy_task = env.deploy_changes(force=params.force)

commit_message:
Creates Certificate and KMIP credential object

Adds Certificate as possible credential object
when using Castellan. Also adds kmip as a separate key
manager section inside the default conf file.
Tests are also added for the new credential object.
This is one of 2 patches needed to implement the
KMIP key manager. The second patch will include the
actual KMIP key manager, tests, and more documentation.

Change-Id: Id1b2ab9f1b0317585af6410f4711dd5201825c85
Partially-Implements: blueprint kmip-key-manager
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/castellan refs/changes/04/288704/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_certificate_credential(self): certfile = '/my/path/to/cert.crt' self.config_fixture.config( auth_type='certificate', group='key_manager', certfile=certfile ) certificate_context = utils.credential_factory(conf=CONF) certificate_context_class = certificate_context.__class__.__name__ self.assertEqual('Certificate', certificate_context_class) self.assertEqual(certfile, certificate_context.certfile) def test_kmip_credential(self): certfile = '/my/path/to/cert.crt' keyfile = '/my/path/to/cert.key' ca_certs = '/my/path/to/ca_certs.crt' host = 'localhost' port = '5696' username = 'username' password = 'password' self.config_fixture.config( auth_type='kmip', group='key_manager', certfile=certfile, keyfile=keyfile, ca_certs=ca_certs, host=host, port=port, username=username, password=password ) kmip_context = utils.credential_factory(conf=CONF) kmip_context_class = kmip_context.__class__.__name__ self.assertEqual('KMIP', kmip_context_class) self.assertEqual(certfile, kmip_context.certfile)

commit_message:
Generate a log with deprecation warnings

Makes it easier for folks to go look in one spot for
deprecation warnings spit out in various process(es).
This will also help us warn folks to go fix deprecated
stuff before they become a problem.

Change-Id: I757821bd6f19a168888df92d416d7af16f41637b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/01/289901/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Collect all the deprecation related messages into a single file. # strip out date(s), timestamp(s), pid(s), context information and # remove duplicates as well so we have a limited set of lines to # look through. grep -i deprecat $BASE/logs/*.log | \ sed -r 's/[0-9]{1,2}\:[0-9]{1,2}\:[0-9]{1,2}\.[0-9]{1,3}/ /g' | \ sed -r 's/[0-9]{1,2}\:[0-9]{1,2}\:[0-9]{1,2}/ /g' | \ sed -r 's/[0-9]{1,4}-[0-9]{1,2}-[0-9]{1,4}/ /g' | sed -r 's/\[.*\]/ /g' | \ sed -r 's/\s[0-9]+\s/ /g' | \ awk '!seen[$0]++' > $BASE/logs/deprecations.log

commit_message:
keystone/wsgi: bind on local IP

Instead of using default value from puppetlabs-apache and use 0.0.0.0
binding, let's use local IP like it was done before when running
eventlet.

Also cleaning some useless parameters for keystone binding, that are not
used anymore since we run WSGI.

Change-Id: Id84b05e7a855d1452236c89224eed507c58b03a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/99/272699/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ssl => false, bind_host => hiera('controller_host'),
deleted_lines: public_bind_host => hiera('controller_host'), admin_bind_host => hiera('controller_host'), ssl => false,

commit_message:
Add documentation for the IPMITool driver

This patch is adding the documentation for the IPMITool driver. This
covers some general overview, basic setup (prerequisites, how to enable)
as well as some advanced topics such as single/double bridge and protocol
version.

The IPMITool driver is rich and allows a lot of configuration, therefore
not all topics are addressed by this commit. TODOs were left in the
documentation (as comments) so we don't forget to address them later.

Partial-Bug: #1468710
Change-Id: Ife99de75a42d7048fd1ad31e220b5606a8fe81f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/18/290718/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _IPMITOOL: =============== IPMITool driver =============== Overview ======== The IPMITool driver enables managing nodes by using the Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) versions 2.0 or 1.5. The name of the driver comes from the utility `ipmitool`_ which is an open-source command-line interface (CLI) for controlling IPMI-enabled devices. Currently there are 2 IPMITool drivers: * ``agent_ipmitool`` * ``pxe_ipmitool`` Glossary ======== * IPMI - Intelligent Platform Management Interface * IPMB - Intelligent Platform Management Bus/Bridge * BMC - Baseboard Management Controller * RMCP - Remote Management Control Protocol Prerequisites ============= * The `ipmitool`_ utility should be installed on the ironic conductor node. Enabling the IPMITool driver(s) =============================== .. note:: The ``pxe_ipmitool`` driver is the default driver in Ironic, so if no extra configuration is provided the driver will be enabled. #. Add ``pxe_ipmitool`` and/or ``agent_ipmitool`` to the list of ``enabled_drivers`` in */etc/ironic/ironic.conf*. For example:: [DEFAULT] ... enabled_drivers = pxe_ipmitool,agent_ipmitool #. Restart the Ironic conductor service:: service ironic-conductor restart Registering a node with the IPMItool driver =========================================== Nodes configured to use the IPMItool drivers should have the ``driver`` property set to ``pxe_ipmitool`` or ``agent_ipmitool``. The following configuration value is required and have to be added to the node's ``driver_info`` field: - ``ipmi_address``: The IP address or hostname of the BMC. Other options may be needed to match the configuration of the BMC, the following options are optional, but in most cases, it's considered a good practice to have them set: - ``ipmi_username``: The username to access the BMC; defaults is *NULL* user. - ``ipmi_password``: The password to access the BMC; defaults to *NULL*. - ``ipmi_port``: The remote IPMI RMCP port. By default ipmitool will use the port *623*. The ``ironic node-create`` command can be used to enroll a node with the IPMITool driver. For example:: ironic node-create -d pxe_ipmitool -i ipmi_address=<address> -i ipmi_username=<username> -i ipmi_password=<password> Advanced configuration ====================== When a simple configuration such as providing the ``address``, ``username`` and ``password`` is not enough, the IPMItool driver contains many other options that can be used to address special usages. Single/Double bridging functionality ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ There are two different bridging functionalities supported by the IPMITool driver: ``single bridge`` and ``dual bridge``. The following configuration values need to be added to the node's ``driver_info`` field so bridging can be used: - ``ipmi_bridging``: The bridging type; default is *no*; other supported values are *single* for single bridge or *dual* for double bridge. - ``ipmi_local_address``: The local IPMB address for bridged requests. Required only if ``ipmi_bridging`` is set to *single* or *dual*. - ``ipmi_target_address``: The destination address for bridged request. Required only if ``ipmi_bridging`` is set to *single* or *dual*. - ``ipmi_target_channel``: The destination channel for bridged request. Required only if ``ipmi_bridging`` is set to *single* or *dual*. Double bridge specific options: - ``ipmi_transit_address``: The transit address for bridged request. Required only if ``ipmi_bridging`` is set to *dual*. - ``ipmi_transit_channel``: The transit channel for bridged request. Required only if ``ipmi_bridging`` is set to *dual*. The parameter ``ipmi_bridging`` should specify the type of bridging required: *single* or *dual* to access the bare metal node. If the parameter is not specified, the default value will be set to *no*. The ``ironic node-update`` command can be used to set the required bridging information to the Ironic node enrolled with the IPMItool driver. For example: * Single Bridging:: ironic node-update add <UUID or name> driver_info/ipmi_local_address=<address> driver_info/ipmi_bridging=single driver_info/ipmi_target_channel=<channel> driver_info/ipmi_target_address=<target address> * Double Bridging:: ironic node-update add <UUID or name> driver_info/ipmi_local_address=<address> driver_info/ipmi_bridging=dual driver_info/ipmi_transit_channel=<transit channel> driver_info/ipmi_transit_address=<transit address> driver_info/ipmi_target_channel=<target channel> driver_info/ipmi_target_address=<target address> .. note:: For bridging cases the parameter ``ipmi_local_address`` is optional. If the parameter is not specified, it is auto discovered by `ipmitool`_ Changing the version of the IPMI protocol ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The IPMItool driver works with the versions ``2.0`` and ``1.5`` of the IPMI protocol. By default, the version ``2.0`` is used. In order to change the IPMI protocol version in the bare metal node, the following option needs to be set to the node's ``driver_info`` field: - ``ipmi_protocol_version``: The version of the IPMI protocol; default is *2.0*. Supported values are *1.5* or *2.0*. The ``ironic node-update`` command can be used to set the desired protocol version:: ironic node-update add <UUID or name> driver_info/ipmit_protocol_version=<version> .. warning:: The version *1.5* of the IPMI protocol do not support encryption. So it's extremely recommended that the version *2.0* is used. .. TODO(lucasagomes): Write about privilege level .. TODO(lucasagomes): Force boot device .. References: .. _`ipmitool`: https://sourceforge.net/projects/ipmitool

subject: Build AFS RPMs for Centos7 periodically
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-09 01:06:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/5b5954b7e6842a7466ace590a91828556216b198', 'message': '[WIP] initial script for building AFS

initial script for building centos7 AFS modules

Why do this

 * There is no official centos7 AFS rpms provided by either Centos or
   AFS.

 * making puppet-afs do this is one option.  However, it means that
   any non-puppet consumers have to figure this out for themselves.
   This just creates a simple "add repo + install" path

 * There are some less-offical builds around.  However, if we build
   the rpms, we control the versions and code that goes into them, and
   have our own logs for posterity/debugging.

Change-Id: I53e8267b2a0fc31589dd3a1f3e3f3a86175a2e15
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-09 01:48:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/25a0a8fdff2b8a1bed36febf6529ff52b84117fa', 'message': 'Build AFS RPM's for Centos7 periodically

Create a local CentOS7 AFS repo built from upstream.  The idea is to
have this consumed by puppet-afs on a CentOS7 wheel-build host, so it
can publish wheels to the mirrors.

Some motiviations:

 * There is no official/canonical centos7 AFS rpms provided by either
   Centos or AFS [1]

 * making puppet-afs do this is another option.  However, it means
   that any non-puppet consumers have to figure this out for
   themselves, and we need to figure out how to make puppet download
   source, build and install.  This just creates a simple "add repo +
   install" path, which is much simpler for puppet consumers and
   everyone else.

 * There are some less-offical builds around.  If we build the rpms,
   we control the versions and code that goes into them, and have our
   own logs for posterity/debugging.

 * If official repos become available, it's a simple switch and we
   remove this job.

[1]  https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-devel/2015-August/013730.html

Change-Id: I53e8267b2a0fc31589dd3a1f3e3f3a86175a2e15

commit_message:
Build AFS RPMs for Centos7 periodically

Create a local CentOS7 AFS repo built from upstream.  The idea is to
have this consumed by puppet-afs on a CentOS7 wheel-build host, so it
can publish wheels to the mirrors.

Some motiviations:

 * There is no official/canonical centos7 AFS rpms provided by either
   Centos or AFS [1]

 * making puppet-afs do this is another option.  However, it means
   that any non-puppet consumers have to figure this out for
   themselves, and we need to figure out how to make puppet download
   source, build and install.  This just creates a simple "add repo +
   install" path, which is much simpler for puppet consumers and
   everyone else.

 * There are some less-offical builds around.  If we build the rpms,
   we control the versions and code that goes into them, and have our
   own logs for posterity/debugging.

 * If official repos become available, it's a simple switch and we
   remove this job.

[1]  https://lists.centos.org/pipermail/centos-devel/2015-August/013730.html

Change-Id: I53e8267b2a0fc31589dd3a1f3e3f3a86175a2e15
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/14/290214/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eux set -o errexit # There are no official builds for AFS on Centos 7 # This is run by a periodic job to build a repo we publish on # static.openstack.org. This can be consumed by centos hosts that # need access to the AFS mirror # TODO: fedora YUM=${YUM:-yum} VERSION=1.6.16 SRC_VERSION=${VERSION}-1 SRC_RPM=openafs-${SRC_VERSION}.src.rpm SRC_URL=https://www.openafs.org/dl/openafs/${VERSION}/${SRC_RPM} # # TODO : figure out how we can not build every time # If we leave a blank directory, then we'll scp a blank dir and drop # what we have #UPSTREAM_BASE=https://static.openstack.org/pkg-afs-centos7 #UPSTREAM_CHECK=${UPSTREAM_BASE}/openafs-client-${SRC_VERSION}.el7.centos.x86_64.rpm #if wget -O/dev/null -q $UPSTREAM_CHECK; then # echo "Found existing upstream RPM build, nothing to do" # exit 0 #fi # some common prereqs sudo yum -y groupinstall "Development Tools" "Development Libraries" sudo yum -y install rpm-build kernel-devel createrepo wget $SRC_URL # install the build dependencies for the package sudo yum-builddep -y ./${SRC_RPM} # install source-rpm rpm -i ./${SRC_RPM} # build everything pushd rpmbuild/SPECS/ rpmbuild -ba ./openafs.spec popd # create final repo for copying createrepo rpmbuild/RPMS/x86_64

commit_message:
Use common tools to run tests

In order to correspond to global requirements and integrate
depper with OpenStack CI this patch switches shotgun from
py.test and unittest2 to testrepository and oslotest.

Partial-bug: #1469045
Change-Id: Ic0abb5e8e62113be300f871b065f9cc48cd381a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shotgun refs/changes/22/281522/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ostestr {posargs} python setup.py test --coverage {posargs}

commit_message:
Synchronize with global requirements

This patch  allignes both versions and order of packages in requirements.txt
and test-requirements.txt with master revision of OpenStack's global
requirements in Mitaka release cycle.

In order to perform the soft sync all settings from setup.py were moved to
setup.cfg and setup.py was autogenerated using cookiecutter and the default
project template for OpenStack projects.

Partial-bug: #1469045
Change-Id: I9d99517b9016f61904ab5e25d8ffb39cfb0c1119

commit_message:
Fix test_aggregate functional test

Nova API validation changes [1] appear to have broken the
'os aggregate create' and 'nova aggregate-create' commands when
an availability zone name is not specified. This patch set updates
the test_aggregate functional test to set the availability zone
name in order to unblock the osc gate while nova investigates
the issue.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/281143/

Change-Id: I00b497be61c4bc4bc467c66c1e49b2e0636ab841
Related-Bug: #1541691
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/56/288056/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Use the default 'nova' availability zone for the aggregate. raw_output = cls.openstack( 'aggregate create --zone nova ' + cls.NAME + opts )

It has been automatically generated using cookiecutter[1] and msync[2]

[2] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-modulesync-configs

added_lines: # == Class: octavia::keystone::auth # # Configures octavia user, service and endpoint in Keystone. # # === Parameters # # [*password*] # (required) Password for octavia user. # # [*auth_name*] # Username for octavia service. Defaults to 'octavia'. # # [*email*] # Email for octavia user. Defaults to 'octavia@localhost'. # # [*tenant*] # Tenant for octavia user. Defaults to 'services'. # # [*configure_endpoint*] # Should octavia endpoint be configured? Defaults to 'true'. # # [*configure_user*] # (Optional) Should the service user be configured? # Defaults to 'true'. # # [*configure_user_role*] # (Optional) Should the admin role be configured for the service user? # Defaults to 'true'. # # [*service_type*] # Type of service. Defaults to 'octavia'. # # [*region*] # Region for endpoint. Defaults to 'RegionOne'. # # [*service_name*] # (optional) Name of the service. # Defaults to the value of auth_name. # # [*public_url*] # (optional) The endpoint's public url. (Defaults to 'http://127.0.0.1:9876') # This url should *not* contain any trailing '/'. # # [*admin_url*] # (optional) The endpoint's admin url. (Defaults to 'http://127.0.0.1:9876') # This url should *not* contain any trailing '/'. # # [*internal_url*] # (optional) The endpoint's internal url. (Defaults to 'http://127.0.0.1:9876') # class octavia::keystone::auth ( $password, $auth_name = 'octavia', $email = 'octavia@localhost', $tenant = 'services', $configure_endpoint = true, $configure_user = true, $configure_user_role = true, $service_name = undef, $service_type = 'octavia', $region = 'RegionOne', $public_url = 'http://127.0.0.1:9876', $admin_url = 'http://127.0.0.1:9876', $internal_url = 'http://127.0.0.1:9876', ) { $real_service_name = pick($service_name, $auth_name) keystone::resource::service_identity { 'octavia': configure_user => $configure_user, configure_user_role => $configure_user_role, configure_endpoint => $configure_endpoint, service_name => $real_service_name, service_type => $service_type, service_description => 'Octavia Service', region => $region, auth_name => $auth_name, password => $password, email => $email, tenant => $tenant, public_url => $public_url, internal_url => $internal_url, admin_url => $admin_url, } }

Clean up ml2/sg_callback.py

In the method subscribe(self) of sg_callback.py, there was some
comments line that needed to be clean up. This patch will help
to remove those comments.

Closes-Bug: #1549591

commit_message:
Sync cgroups implementation details

Change-Id: I24300031a13bf675ed8d4fabd696cf087b123198
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/29/287729/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: User will be able to move all services described above under cgroups resources control. User should prepare special configuration JSON string for each service what supposed to be moved under the cgroups control(cgroups utils will be installed even if no cgroup's settings were specified). User will be able to specify limits via API/CLI (one more field will be brought into yaml with cluster's settings structure by user). New puppet task to apply cgroups configuration on target nodes will be added as well.New hidden section `cgroups` should be added into openstack.yaml file under 'general' group to make cgroups settings configurable after the cluster is deployed. User will be able to download/upload cluster's settings file to override default cgroups settings(add new services and settings). Example of a new structure what's supposed to be added into openstack.yaml file by ( the nesting level - ['editable']['additional_components']): always_editable: true ... Example of services what should be added under cgroups control: .. code-block:: yamlexplicitly described in feature's documentation.Cloud operator should add services what supposed to be moved under cgroups control into cluster's settings file via CLI(into cgroups section), data from corresponding section will be included into node's astute yaml file automatically during the serialization process. role: '*'* Introduce cgroups section into openstack.yaml file
deleted_lines: All described services above will be moved under cgroups resources control, but cgroups limits will not be activated by default. So cgroups profiles will be configured for proposed resources without specified limits if they were not explicitly stated by the user. User will be able to specify limits via API/CLI (one more field will be brought into yaml with cluster's settings structure by user). New puppet task to apply cgroups configuration on target nodes will be added as well.Cloud operator should add `cgroups` section into downloaded cluster's settings file to override default cgroups settings. Example of a new structure what's supposed to be added into cluster's settings.yaml file by cloud operator( the nesting level - ['editable']['additional_components']):New block 'cgroups' will be introduced into cluster's settings tab under 'general' group.explicitly described in feature's documetation.Cloud operator should add 'cgroup' section into cluster's settings file via CLI, data from corresponding section will be included into node's astute yaml file automatically during the serialization process. groups: ['/.*/']

commit_message:
Use pymysql database driver for OpenStack DBs

PyMySQL is a new driver introduced in Liberty.
This patch change the MySQL url to use mysql+pymysql like recommanded.

Closes-Bug: #1499298
Depends-On: If41a86abc3090dfb439d09cd63ae2ecb9a0b9598
Change-Id: I1b49a86f0bb4b410620e280b7e53c32c5186b1f7

commit_message:
Update python-troveclient deliverable for mitaka

Version 2.1.0 of the python-troveclient included a change that broke
compatibility. This change is to request that 2.1.1 (which has the fix
for the compatibility) be released with Mitaka.

This however is subject to the fact that Trove has a change that was
granted an FFE, and that change has a client side component. That
change (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/290177/) will land and then I
will request 2.2.0 be tagged.

Change-Id: I5f113c7e4a3af50b34c1cceb542ffc5a71d9395c
Related-Bug: #1538506
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/62/291162/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: - version: 2.1.0 hash: 9165c47123255fc76e86901117d9591226d5f992 - Add support for Module Maintenance Commands. - Add support for Guest Log File Retrieval.

commit_message:
OVS Agent extension for bagpipe driver

This change introduces an OVS L2 agent extension that will now be used
instead of the previous agent in ovs_bagpipe_neutron_agent.py which
was inheriting from the Neutron OVS agent in a crude way, requiring
duplicating the main() code.

We also remove mention of the old bagpipe-openvswitch agent
in the documentation and and adapt the devstack plugin so that
old local.conf will still work.

Change-Id: Ibf27e2b028efffa1e49207d39bfc9b13464180ad
Closes-Bug: 1492021
Closes-Bug: 1531459
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn refs/changes/58/281358/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Orange. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ L2 Agent extension to support bagpipe networking-bgpvpn driver RPCs in the OpenVSwitch agent """ import netaddr import logging from neutron._i18n import _, _LE, _LI, _LW from neutron.agent.l2 import agent_extension from neutron_lib import constants as n_const from neutron.common import topics from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.openvswitch.agent.common import constants \ as ovs_agt_constants from networking_bagpipe.agent import bagpipe_bgp_agent from networking_bagpipe.agent.bgpvpn.rpc_client import topics_BAGPIPE_BGPVPN #from networking_bgpvpn.neutron.services.service_drivers.bagpipe. #need to move RPC definitions to networking-bgpvpn...bagpipe # bagpipe-l2 will not need them, since it would simply load this extension # ... # we possibly would need two slightly different extensions for OVS # and linuxbridge ? LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class BagpipeBgpvpnAgentExtension(agent_extension.AgentCoreResourceExtension): def initialize(self, connection, driver_type): if driver_type != ovs_agt_constants.EXTENSION_DRIVER_TYPE: raise Exception("This extension is designed to work with the" " OVS Agent") # Create an HTTP client for BaGPipe BGP component REST service self.bgp_agent = bagpipe_bgp_agent.BaGPipeBGPAgent( n_const.AGENT_TYPE_OVS, int_br=self.int_br,#ok tun_br=self.tun_br,#ok ) self._register_rpc_consumers(connection) def _register_rpc_consumers(self, connection): endpoints = [self.bgp_agent] connection.create_consumer(topics.get_topic_name(topics.AGENT, topics_BAGPIPE_BGPVPN, topics.UPDATE), endpoints, fanout=True) connection.create_consumer(topics.get_topic_name(topics.AGENT, topics_BAGPIPE_BGPVPN, topics.UPDATE, self.conf.host), endpoints, fanout=False) def consume_api(self, agent_api): self.br_int = agent_api.request_int_br() self.br_tun = agent_api.request_tun_br()

commit_message:
Use pkg_resources to get version

Current osprofiler can't show version due to
wrong way to generate module version.
Use pkg_resources to get version.

Note: we don't want to usr pbr in runtime.

Closes-Bug: #1551079

Renamed 'TRIGGERED' state to 'PENDING'

Following the change in Watcher, this patchset updates the
Watcher Dashboard to support this change.

subject: Use SensitiveStringField for BlockDeviceMapping.connection_info
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-05 18:44:30.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/objects/test_objects.py', 'nova/objects/block_device.py', 'nova/objects/fields.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/db50aaca0acdf7814a8d6673545db94738907131', 'message': "Use SensitiveStringField for BlockDeviceMapping.connection_info

bd977f400a1192d5cf7c2b52ef91615c0828813c added the SensitiveStringField
to oslo.versionedobjects. SensitiveStringField is a StringField, which
is what BlockDeviceMapping.connection_info was already using. The difference
is that a SensitiveStringField masks passwords in the 'stringify' method,
which is what's used when __repr__ is called on the object.

Since BDM.connection_info can contain credentials, and the connection_info
dict gets passed around quite a bit in the compute manager and virt drivers,
it has from time to time gotten logged without first masking passwords.

This makes the object handle masking the password so we don't have to do it
explicitly anymore.

There is no version bump on the BlockDeviceMapping object since nothing has
functionally changed.

Change-Id: I66a0b5f6834034e2fcbefc4510e3aa018edec310
Closes-Bug: #1321785
"}]
commit_message:
Use SensitiveStringField for BlockDeviceMapping.connection_info

bd977f400a1192d5cf7c2b52ef91615c0828813c added the SensitiveStringField
to oslo.versionedobjects. SensitiveStringField is a StringField, which
is what BlockDeviceMapping.connection_info was already using. The difference
is that a SensitiveStringField masks passwords in the 'stringify' method,
which is what's used when __repr__ is called on the object.

Since BDM.connection_info can contain credentials, and the connection_info
dict gets passed around quite a bit in the compute manager and virt drivers,
it has from time to time gotten logged without first masking passwords.

This makes the object handle masking the password so we don't have to do it
explicitly anymore.

There is no version bump on the BlockDeviceMapping object since nothing has
functionally changed.

Change-Id: I66a0b5f6834034e2fcbefc4510e3aa018edec310
Closes-Bug: #1321785
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/27/288927/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SensitiveStringField = fields.SensitiveStringField

subject: Fix oslo master jobs failures - missing upper constraints
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-10 14:04:36.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/python-jobs.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/11214509c13ae512d49ec4101cdd3e7aeb3692e2', 'message': 'Fix oslo master jobs failures - missing upper constraints

Looks like there were changes in the CI system which we
need to catch up with:
http://logs.openstack.org/periodic/periodic-nova-py27-with-oslo-master/bc1a2b8/console.html#_2016-03-10_06_04_18_695

the failure is because UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is
set in run-tox.sh and we need to switch to
zuul-git-branch-prep-upper-constraints so that
the upper-constaints.txt is fetched.

Change-Id: I8a8b4a7da838c62be6b42500b2167d63a553035e
'}]
commit_message:
Fix oslo master jobs failures - missing upper constraints

Looks like there were changes in the CI system which we
need to catch up with:
http://logs.openstack.org/periodic/periodic-nova-py27-with-oslo-master/bc1a2b8/console.html#_2016-03-10_06_04_18_695

the failure is because UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is
set in run-tox.sh and we need to switch to
zuul-git-branch-prep-upper-constraints so that
the upper-constaints.txt is fetched.

Change-Id: I8a8b4a7da838c62be6b42500b2167d63a553035e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/93/291193/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - zuul-git-branch-prep-upper-constraints:

added_lines: .. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Vitrage API ----------- | .. contents:: Contents: :local: Overview ******** **This document describes the Vitrage API v1.** **The Vitrage API provides a RESTful JSON interface for interacting with Vitrage Engine.** List Versions ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Lists the supported versions of the Vitrage API. GET / ~~~~~ Headers ======= - X-Auth-Token (string, required) - Keystone auth token - Accept (string) - application/json Path Parameters =============== None. Query Parameters ================ None. Request Body ============ None. Request Examples ================ :: GET / HTTP/1.1 Host: 135.248.19.18:8999 X-Auth-Token: 2b8882ba2ec44295bf300aecb2caa4f7 Accept: application/json ResponseStatus code =================== - 200 - OK Response Body ============= Returns a JSON object with a 'links' array of links of supported versions. Response Examples ================= :: { "versions": [ { "id": "v1.0", "links": [ { "href": "http://135.248.19.18:8999/v1/", "rel": "self" } ], "status": "CURRENT", "updated": "2015-11-29" } ] } Get topology ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Get the topology for the node. Its possible to filter the edges vertices and depth of the graph POST /v1/topology/ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Headers ======= - X-Auth-Token (string, required) - Keystone auth token - Accept (string) - application/json Path Parameters =============== None. Query Parameters ================ None Request Body ============ Consists of a topology request definition which has the following properties: * root - (string, optional) the root node to start. defaults to the openstack node * depth - (int, optional) the depth of the topology graph. defaults to max depth * graph_type-(string, optional) can be either tree or graph. defaults to graph * query - (string, optional) a json query filter to filter the graph components. defaults to return all the graph query expression ================ :: query := expression expression := simple_expression|complex_expression simple_expression := {simple_operator: {field_name: value}} simple_operator := = | != | < | <= | > | >= complex_expression := {complex_operator: [expression, expression, ...]} | not_expression not_expression := {not: expression} complex_operator := and | or Query example ============= :: POST /v1/topology/ Host: 135.248.19.18:8999 Content-Type: application/json X-Auth-Token: 2b8882ba2ec44295bf300aecb2caa4f7 { "query" : { "or": [ "=": { "type":"host" }, "=": { "type":"instance" }, "=": { "type":"zone" }, "=": { "type":"node" } ] } "graph_type" : "tree" limit : 4 } Response Status Code ==================== - 200 - OK - 400 - Bad request Response Body ============= Returns a JSON object that describes a graph with nodes and links. If a tree representation is asked then returns a Json tree with nodes and children. An error of cannot represent as a tree will be return if the graph is not a tree. (400 - Bad request) Response Examples ================= :: { "directed": true, "graph": {}, "nodes": [ { "category": "RESOURCE", "is_placeholder": false, "is_deleted": false, "name": "vm-8", "RESOURCE:nova.instance:20d12a8a-ea9a-89c6-5947-83bea959362e" }, { "category": "RESOURCE", "is_placeholder": false, "is_deleted": false, "name": "vm-2", "update_timestamp": "2015-12-01T12:46:41Z",
